PETITION.TITLE: National Health Promotion Foundation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That the constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

(2) Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

(3) Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the states and weakens the role of the Senate.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal for or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service.
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is he also aware that the Commission, in a hearing on the dispute, has described the Australian Capital Territory building industry as being in a state of anarchy and said that the union was supporting liars and frauds and that events on the site raised a question of criminal action? Is he aware that the staff of White Constructions (ACT) Pty Ltd have been intimidated, abused and physically assaulted in relation to the dispute and that the car door of the industrial relations director of the Master Builders Association (MBA) was smashed in while he was attending a meeting at the site? Is the Government aware that there is a complaint that elements of the union movement have attempted to blackmail members of the council and executive of the MBA into silencing the Association from putting these facts forward? I ask: Why has the Government not responded to the MBA's letter of 23 March seeking assistance in dealing with this appalling situation? What is the Government's attitude to the state of anarchy in the Australian Capital Territory building industry? What action is the Government taking to deal with the matter?
—I am not aware of all the matters which Senator Chaney refers to in his question.
—You darn well ought to be.

—Thank you, Senator. As I said, I am not aware of all the matters which Senator Chaney refers to in his question but I will endeavour to obtain an answer as quickly as possible. Some of the allegations involve criminality. That is a matter appropriate for the police. In so far as the pure industrial relations matters are concerned, I will ask the Minister to give us an early answer. Certainly, for example, I am not aware of the letter of 23 March and any response to it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer and ask for a speedy response. My supplementary question relates to his point about some of the allegations giving rise to the possibility that there have been criminal offences. I ask the Minister: Will he confirm that the fact that criminal offences may take place in some sort of connection with an industrial dispute will not be regarded by the Government as in any sense providing cover or an excuse for such action and that these matters should be investigated even though there is a suggestion of some connection with an industrial dispute?
—Of course not.
—They should not be investigated?

—If a criminal action is involved and the allegations are ones of criminality, the fact that it is alleged to have the character of an industrial dispute by some people has nothing to do with it. It is criminal action.

—Does the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer agree that productivity improvements are necessary for Australia to improve its international competitiveness? If so, is the Minister persuaded by the argument that the demolition of the Commonwealth system of conciliation and arbitration tribunals would lead to a more efficient allocation of the nation's labour resources and thus to improved productivity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were three parts to the question. The answer to the first two parts is yes. On the question of whether the Government is persuaded about demolitions and so on, I think those who believe that argument are really referring to what some commentators call closed shop arrangements, which are alleged to be detrimental to the allocation of labour. These people usually add that conciliation and arbitration tribunals encourage and support closed shop arrangements and hence the abolition of the conciliation and arbitration tribunals would end the closed shop and improve productivity.

ANSWER.PARA: Contained in that argument is one major fallacy. A recent publication put out by the Australian Institute for Public Policy, with which, as some people would know, a former member of the House of Representatives, John Hyde, is associated, contained an article written by Dufty and Mulvey, entitled `The sources of Union Power'. It states:
Such arrangements-
that is, closed shop arrangements-
are not included in awards: no tribunal has the power to order or approve a closed shop.

So, whether a closed shop is a good idea or not, it is untrue to say that the existence of closed shops depends upon conciliation and arbitration tribunals. Therefore, it follows logically and inescapably that the abolition of conciliation and arbitration tribunals, far from reducing the incidence of closed shops, would be more likely to increase it as bargaining at a plant or company level replaced the awards of tribunals. It is more likely that with more emphasis on bargaining there would be more closed shops.

The Dufty and Mulvey study goes on to report that, of the closed shop arrangements that exist in Australia, the overwhelming majority are post-entry closed shops and that 70 per cent of them are the result of agreements at the level of the plant or firm, which emphasises the point I was making earlier. Closed shop arrangements are by no means restricted to the industrial workplace or agreements negotiated usually with the assistance of unions or what people usually regard as unions. If one extends the definition of `union' to include the lawyers union in Queensland-that is, the Queensland Law Society-one finds that it, too, has a closed shop. The Australian Financial Review of 30 March reported that Queensland rules do not allow interstate solicitors to practise in Queensland, and that legal firms which have interstate associations are not permitted to advertise those associations. That rule, I assume, is dependent upon an Act or regulation of the Queensland Government. The Queensland lawyers union-that is, the Queensland Law Society-decided on 29 March that it would retain those closed shop arrangements, which makes me wonder about Senator Stone, who thundered about closed shops in a speech in Perth last week. He said:
The closed shop with all its terrible consequences for the present freedoms, and civil liberties more generally, of those who are ground beneath its heel, cannot any longer be tolerated.

I therefore anticipate that Senator Stone will use his undoubted influence with the National Party in Queensland to see that the closed shop reinforced by the Queensland lawyers union a couple of weeks ago will be abolished in Queensland. A little further down the track, I look forward to him opening up the biggest closed shop of them all-the Queensland sugar industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to comments made in recent days by the Federation of Metal Trades Unions about the Minister's refusal to end speculation about across-the-board tariff cuts. Has the Government agreed to meet with unions to discuss any destabilisation of manufacturing which may be created by major tariff cuts? Has the Government's decision on this issue been influenced by the metal trade unions' threat to wage a campaign for a 17 per cent pay increase in retaliation for across-the-board tariff cuts? Can the Minister give an assurance that any meeting with unions is part of a general process of consultation with all interested parties and is not simply placing powerful unions above business and consumers? Finally, will the Minister give an undertaking that he will state the Government's policy on industry protection to Parliament before informing the unions of the Government's policy on industry protection?

—The first part of the question was: Has the Government agreed to meet with unions regarding this matter? The answer to that part of the question is yes. Secondly, is the Government responding to a threat by the metal workers unions in relation to this matter? The answer is no. If the threat which Senator Lewis identified were carried into effect by the metal unions we probably would not have any metal unions in a few years time. I do not think the Government could respond to that threat. Thirdly, is this part of a general process of consultation? There is always a general process of consultation with various parties by this Government. The views of the Business Council of Australia, for example, have been expressed both publicly and elsewhere. The views of the unions on this matter will be expressed to the Government. The views of the Australian Manufacturing Council will be expressed to the Government on these issues. I regard that as a worthwhile process.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BUSINESS COUNCIL OF AUSTRALIA: ECONOMIC PROPOSALS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance seen an article in today's Australian Financial Review quoting the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, as saying that the $2,500m in cuts to Commonwealth Government spending proposed by the Business Council of Australia (BCA) did not go far enough? Do the BCA's proposals include incorporating the value of the family home in the age pension assets test? What pressure has been exerted on or representations made to the Government seeking alterations to the assets test for age pensions? Will the Government be implementing a change on the basis of that pressure or those representations? Finally, what is the cost of altering the age pension assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in today's Australian Financial Review. Before reading the article I had heard that the Business Council had called for cuts of $2.5 billion in the Commonwealth Government's own spending, plus another $1 billion in funding to the States. The Financial Review reports the shadow Treasurer as saying that the BCA submission did not go nearly far enough. The new macho man, the shadow Treasurer, said that a mere $2.5 billion off Commonwealth spending is not nearly enough.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Since the Minister has just woken me up, I assume that he is debating the question again. I would ask you, Mr President, to remind him that the Standing Orders do not permit him to debate the question, which he clearly has commenced doing.
—I will listen carefully to the Minister's answer.

—Thank you, Mr President. I do not believe that I was debating the question. I was just pointing out the facts which are relevant to answering the question. I was asked whether the Business Council's proposals included incorporating the value of the family home in the pension assets text. The Financial Review certainly stated that the BCA had called for that. Whatever one might think of the merit of that, the plain fact is that the BCA proposed not only retention of the assets test, but a major tightening up of the assets test. Whatever merit that policy may have, it is one that has been explicitly rejected both by the would-be macho man who is the shadow Treasurer and by that other would-be macho man, his leader, who, in his reply to the Budget in 1986, said:

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of this review-
that is, a review of Opposition spending commitments-

In conclusion, on the one hand the would-be macho man is saying that the BCA proposal does not go nearly far enough, but on the other hand, on the only specific issue addressed, he will not go nearly as far as the BCA has gone.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORTH QUEENSLAND RAINFORESTS: WORLD HERITAGE LISTING

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of the alleged independent assessment by the Queensland Government of the need for $950m compensation for the World Heritage listing of the north Queensland rainforests? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the basis of this assessment? Does the Minister believe that this is a realistic figure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Queensland Government's claim, which is based on something called the Cameron McNamara study. Just what that study was, I am unable to say. But I am able to say that the figure of $950m is, to say the least, extraordinary. For a start, it is already acknowledged that more than half of that sum relates to the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric scheme. That is worth more than $500m. It is still the subject of a feasibility study by the Queensland Government. Not even the Queensland Government has made a decision to proceed with it, let alone see it prohibited by World Heritage listing. Furthermore, from the diagrams that have been shown to us, very little of that project would intrude into the World Heritage area, anyway. Given that the World Heritage convention allows for acts of economic necessity, it would be very difficult for the Government to attempt to prohibit such an undertaking; rather, obviously, we would seek to make sure that it was done in as sensitive a manner as possible with respect to the environment.

ANSWER.PARA: So it is ludicrous to suggest that that should be part of any figure for compensation when not only has the Queensland Government not made a decision to continue but also the Commonwealth Government has not made a decision to knock it back, anyway. This claim, therefore, is more than ambit; it is in the realm of fantasy land. It has to be put into perspective. The last figures the Australian Bureau of Statistics has for north Queensland-for 1984-85-show that the timber industry in north Queensland was worth $43m per annum. It was worth less than 5 per cent of the north Queensland economy, which rated at more than $3 billion. Manufacturing, apart from the timber industry, was worth almost $1.4 billion. Since 1984-85 the quota for rainforest timber has more than halved, so the value of the industry could not be anything like that figure. Not only would the value be less than 5 per cent, but one would imagine that it would be getting down to the realm of 3 per cent. The cost of the Federal Government's heritage listing decision has been put at $950m. While I would be the first to acknowledge that the economy of north Queensland is booming, no economy can boom that much. One could arrive at that figure only by suggesting that the whole of the north Queensland economy would be destroyed by the decision. No-one would suggest that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even Ronnie Boswell says that.

—That is right, Senator Walsh; not even Senator Boswell says that. These sorts of ridiculous claims do nothing to assist either north Queenslanders affected by the decision or the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources team here at the moment to evaluate the listing. While it is a ridiculous assertion, it is also obvious that a number of mills will remain open, that the effects of the Government's decision have been wildly exaggerated and, most importantly, that the Commonwealth package of $75m not only adds up to jobs for hundreds of north Queenslanders but also means that the regional economy can take advantage of a tourism infrastructure that can be greatly assisted with that money.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. My attention has been drawn to a recent article in the Accountant expressing concern regarding the advertising of interest rates. Has the Trade Practices Commission taken action to halt the practice of many financial institutions of quoting interest rates purely in nominal terms, and, in the light of the Commission's own stated aim of minimising the potential for misleading conduct, has the Government taken steps to ensure the difference between nominal rates and effective rates is made clear to people considering loans to ensure that every Australian borrowing money is aware of the true rate of interest he or she is paying?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that I do not have a brief on the attitude of the Trade Practices Commission to the advertising of interest rates. I will certainly secure an answer as soon as possible as to the view taken by that body. I must say that of course it is of great concern when consumers, beguiled by very effective advertising into making a purchase, are misled into not correctly identifying the real or effective rate of interest they may be required to pay in order to secure the object of their desire, the purchase that they wish to make. That discrepancy between the advertised interest rate and the effective outlay over a period of time is quite large on occasions, and that is a situation which ought to be remedied. I believe that is occurring in some jurisdictions. It may be covered by State consumer protection legislation and so on, with which my colleague Senator Bolkus is probably more familiar than I, whereby such requirements are made so that the purchaser does know exactly how much he or she has to outlay by the end of the period.

ANSWER.PARA: It may also be the case that this matter has added urgency, in so far as consumer bankruptcies are really more of a worry than business bankruptcies, because of the scale of the problem; and it would be well known that the Government has in mind organising a conference which will look especially at the problem of consumer credit and the associated advertising which can lead people to make commitments far beyond their means. I will certainly look to the specific question of the Trade Practices Commission's attitude towards this matter but, in general, it is a matter with which the Government is concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORTHERN TERRITORY: UNITED STATES BASES PROPOSAL

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of proposals by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Hatton, to offer the whole of the Cox Peninsula, west of Darwin, to the United States to develop a deep sea harbour and other facilities as a replacement site for the United States naval base at Subic Bay in the Philippines? Can the Minister seek advice from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on the consequences for the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory of such a proposal and from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories on the environmental impact of such a move? Does the Minister agree with the statement of Galarrwuy Yunupingu, of the Northern Land Council, that the Chief Minister is either badly informed or incompetent-dare we say both? Does the Minister agree that, if this hare-brained notion were implemented, the social consequences for the people of the Northern Territory as a whole would be disastrous? Will the Government categorically denounce this particular proposal and, further, will the Government reassure Australians, in particular residents around Jervis Bay, that Australia will refuse to host a replacement base for Subic Bay?

—The Defence Minister has heard of reports of the Northern Territory Chief Minister's proposal. The United States does not wish to replace its facilities at Subic Bay in the Philippines. The United States has not approached the Australian Government seeking alternative sites for these facilities in Australia. A base in Australia could not satisfactorily replace the facilities at Subic Bay because we are too far south of the main focus of US deployments in the Western Pacific. The Government does not intend to approach the United States, as the Northern Territory Chief Minister proposes. Instead, we have stressed the important contribution which the US facilities in the Philippines make to regional security, and we are glad to note a similar view expressed over the weekend by the Malaysian Defence Minister. In view of that advice, I do not intend to seek further information from either the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs or the Environment Minister.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Do full time secondary students who have not previously been in full time employment have to wait 13 weeks after they leave school before they can become eligible for the unemployment benefit? If so, can parents of a student who is under the age of 18 years receive, subject to an income test, family allowance until the student obtains work or becomes eligible for the unemployment benefit? Can family allowance be similarly paid for a former student aged 18 and, if not, could completing students who are 18 be at a distinct disadvantage compared to those under that age?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received advice from the Department on the three specific parts of Senator Colston's question. I am advised that students over 16 leaving secondary school or tertiary education and who are under 21, single and without dependants must serve a deferment period of 13 weeks after leaving that education before unemployment benefit can be paid. During that 13-week period they must also be registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). The Government believes it would be highly undesirable if simply leaving school were to create immediate access to the unemployment benefit. In this respect the requirement for CES registration ensures a closer link between income support and job search activities.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to Senator Colston's second question, the answer is that, while a former student aged 16 to 17 years is serving a deferment period, family allowance can be paid subject to the usual income test on that payment, provided that any educational allowance-that is, Austudy-has ceased and the former student is unemployed and still dependent on his or her parents. Family allowance is also payable to former students in this situation who are aged 18 years or more if their families are in disadvantaged circumstances; that is, if the parents are eligible for pension or benefit, family allowance supplement, orphan's pension or child disability allowance. So in that respect parents of older students, for whom the payment will be most crucial, are not in any way at a disadvantage compared with families of younger students.

I should add that education leavers who are independent of their parents and who are not receiving financial support may also be eligible for special benefit during the deferment period. The Government's objectives in this area are to ensure that measures such as these will help ensure that the closer integration of family, education and unemployment payments does not impose unfair burdens on students or parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the report of the Australian Automotive Industry Authority upon which last Wednesday's statement of changes to the passenger motor vehicle plan was based. I ask the Minister: Did the Authority recommend that any or all of the report be published? Will the Minister publicly release the report? If not, why not? Are the Government's decisions announced on 13 April 1988 fully consistent with the recommendations in the report? Finally, given that the industry is currently producing about 100,000 units a year less than what might be regarded as its traditional base of production, what did the Authority recommend for the industry to recover that base?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most people understand, although Senator Chapman clearly does not, that the decline in the industry's fortunes in the last two years is very much due to a variety of more macro-economic factors. We cannot wave any magic wand which will produce demand for the motor vehicle industry as an aspect of the industry's policy. The essential reasons why there has been a decline in the car market, as I said to Senator Lewis at our last Question Time, I think, were, first of all, the depreciation of the Australian dollar, which had a very big effect on prices for both imported cars and components for locally manufactured cars and, secondly, the fact that under the Government's wages policy in the last few years there has been a downward pressure on wages, with the result that people have had less spending power. Senator Chapman will be aware of that because those opposite keep talking about it.
—And the government taxes.

—I have had a couple of interjections to help me along the way. People say that the reduced market for the car industry is a result of government charges. That was certainly true for a period in 1986 when the fringe benefits tax was first introduced. There is no doubt that the uncertainty associated with that caused a fall in the market. Nonetheless, I think a motor vehicle is still a good fringe benefit compared with other fringe benefits that used to be offered. So I do not think that is an ongoing effect of great significance.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chapman also asked me about the report of the Automotive Industry Authority and whether the Authority recommended that the report be published. As I recall it, no recommendation was made on that issue. The Authority will shortly be publishing its stated industry report and its recommendations to me will probably be included in that. If not, the question of the publication of the report can be looked at. No decision has been made about it. I am not seeking to say that it should not be released.

Finally, the honourable senator asked: Was the Government's decision consistent with the recommendations of the Automotive Industry Authority? The answer to that question is yes, although it was not the same in every detail. The Government made some decisions which were different from the initial recommendations of the Authority, but those decisions which were different were discussed with the Authority in the course of reaching a solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs seen an article in the Sydney Morning Herald today reporting Senator Stone's views on immigration, supporting the Blainey view? Is the Minister concerned that the longstanding bipartisan approach to Australian immigration has been abandoned as a result of outbursts of this type?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not concerned that the bipartisan approach to immigration will be abandoned because, fortunately, Senator Stone is not the Opposition spokesperson on immigration. I certainly could have my differences with Mr Cadman and Senator Short, but I take this occasion to pay tribute to them for most of the views that they have expressed in recent months in regard to immigration policies. Successive governments have had a bipartisan commitment to Australia's global non-discriminatory policy and applicants are assessed, regardless of race, religion or ethnic origin, against universal selection criteria. Multiculturalism policies recognise that the diversity of ethnic backgrounds in this country is a strength. It does not threaten the social cohesion of this country; it is based on equal rights and opportunities for all Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: I noted the article in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning headed, `Stone stirs the ethnic mix'. I think that is a particularly provocative headline though, of course, it is not necessarily of Senator Stone's choice; nevertheless, he questions cultural compatibility in this context. I am not quite sure what Senator Stone means by this and perhaps on some occasion in this chamber he would care to outline just what his views are on immigration. I think it is highly embarrassing for the coalition to have Senator Stone speaking out in this way. I know that he did not have very much success in regard to his views on a consumption tax last week and apparently this week he thought he would try another tack. I do not believe that immigration is an issue that can be used in this political way. I think it is very important for the future of this country that all sides of the political spectrum adopt a very cohesive, bipartisan approach to immigration.

TALK.START.PARA: —All sides should agree with the Labor Party; is that your view?

—I am sorry that Senator Stone's interjections seem to suggest that he does have a different view. Professor Blainey has made some statements on this matter in the past and I think he has queried the ethnic mix of recent migrants. I think it is appropriate on this occasion just to quote some statistics that might, for once, set this debate in some context. The Statistics Monthly of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs dated March 1988 refers to the 1986-87 intake from the top 10 source countries-the percentage total intake from a number of countries. For those whose country of birth was the United Kingdom or Ireland, the figure was 19.9 per cent; New Zealand, 12 per cent; Vietnam, 5.9 per cent; the Philippines, 5.6 per cent; South Africa, 4.1 per cent; Malaysia, 3.5 per cent; China, 3.1 per cent; Hong Kong, 3 per cent; Lebanon, 2.5 per cent; and Sri Lanka, 2.5 per cent. Senator Stone and Senator Sheil have gone on record in regard to their views on non-English speaking migrants. I think that anyone who is reasonably quick at mathematics would be able, by doing a quick calculation, to see that by far the great majority of those migrants do in fact speak English, and that those who do not should obviously be offered every assistance and encouragement with English tuition when they are accepted to settle in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I suggest to Senator Stone, who, after all, is a fellow Queensland senator, that he does not seem to be having very much success on the national stage when it comes to policy advice. Perhaps, in view of the results of the Barambah by-election at the weekend, he would do much better to concentrate on his National Party constituency in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Does the Minister recall that in the Senate Estimates Committee E hearing last Thursday, 14 April, he revealed that the final report of the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission will not be available to the Australian Government before it takes decisions on the content of the referendum Bills to be introduced into the House of Representatives on 10 May, or before both the House of Representatives and the Senate have debated the Bills? Therefore, on what bases will the Government be taking its decisions on its referendum Bills? How does the Government expect the electorate to regard other than with cynical contempt the Government's totally inexplicable and unwarranted haste in bringing forward referendum proposals in advance of receiving final advice from the very constitutional committee that it established to advise it and make recommendations on these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall some discussion taking place in Estimates Committee E concerning the relationship between the Constitutional Commission and its various committees, Commission reports, and whatever questions might be put to the people by this Parliament by way of the referendum process. I think it was pointed out that, whilst it may be that the Commission itself will not complete its report until the end of this financial year, it is hoped that the Government will have within the next week or so the benefit of an interim report which will cover some of the matters which may well form the subject of consideration by the Government of the questions which it would like the Parliament to put to the Australian people for their consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: As I think I pointed out on that occasion, there is no necessary relationship between the report of the Commission, whether interim or final, and those questions which the Government might consider worthy of putting by way of referendum, or indeed which might be adopted by this Parliament as being proper to put to the people. Whilst it is obviously beneficial to have the benefit of that report, it is not as though the Government is bound to take the Constitutional Commission's final report as the be-all and end-all in any decision it makes as to the proper questions to put to referendum. We have already been greatly assisted by the committee process of the Constitutional Commission, which has led to the production and consideration in the community and by interested parties of a whole range of very relevant matters. I have no doubt the interim report will be helpful in the same way. The Government will make its decision as to the questions which might be put by way of referendum based on many considerations, including, as I say, those committee reports and one hopes the interim report which will be available at that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer, but he seems not to have answered the basic question, and I repeat it: Why did the Government establish a Constitutional Commission to advise it on constitutional change and then take decisions on constitutional change before it received the final report of the Commission?

—I think it is well known to honourable senators, and I have tried to explain it already, that, given the type of structure which the Commission established, namely the appointment of various committees of high expertise and wide-ranging representation, we have already had put into the public domain very considerable documentation and consideration of the sorts of issues that could properly form the basis for questions to be put by way of referendum. So in a sense the Commission has already performed its major task, if you like, of identifying those questions which are relevant and proper, given Australia's situation in the late twentieth century, for constitutional change, and has already led to that educative process, which is part of its charter, whereby the general public is made aware of those sorts of matters which really do require the attention of the Australian people. Of course, it is always ultimately up to the people as to whether they regard the questions which this Parliament might put to them as sufficiently weighty to merit their passage into a new constitutional provision. But I believe the Constitutional Commission has already justified its existence, regardless of whether it writes another jot or tittle by way of report, by the fact that it has raised in a very professional and considered way and published in its committee reports already the sorts of considerations which will enable government on the one hand and these two chambers on the other properly to frame the sorts of questions which might be put.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's reaction to the recent signing in Geneva of accords providing for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate for me formally to put on the record the extent to which the Australian Government does, very obviously, welcome the signing of the Geneva accords on 14 April. The Geneva accords will provide a framework for the withdrawal of all Soviet troops, which the Government has long recognised as the key element of any settlement in Afghanistan. It is now up to the Soviet Union to honour its commitment to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan and to put an end to its eight-year long occupation of this sovereign country.

ANSWER.PARA: The Geneva accords and the withdrawal of Soviet troops do provide a long overdue opportunity for the Afghan people to decide their own future in accordance with their right to self-determination. While the agreement reached in Geneva holds out the possibility of a better future for the people of Afghanistan, after years of privation and suffering, the Government acknowledges that peace is not yet assured and that much needs to be done to rehabilitate Afghan society and the economy. Australia hopes that in the post-settlement phase the various parties to the dispute within the country will be able to cooperate in the national reconstruction effort. To this end the Australian Government is giving consideration to the provision of emergency assistance for international efforts to facilitate the return of Afghan refugees and to reconstruct the country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HEALTH CARE FOR VISITORS TO AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health read the article in the West Australian of 15 April 1988 which revealed that health officials are issuing Medicare cards and free health insurance to all foreigners who have visas to stay in Australia for at least six months? Is the Minister aware that there are more than 5,000 overseas students attending Western Australian tertiary institutions, a figure expected to jump to 8,500 next year? Bearing in mind that Australia has reciprocal medical rights with only Britain and New Zealand and that virtually all of these students are not from those countries, what does the Minister intend to do to stop this large burden on an already overcrowded public health system and a drain on the public purse?
—The answer to the first of those series of questions is no, I have not seen the article in the West Australian of 15 April.
—Where do you live?

—I did not see that particular article. I saw lots of others on the fifteenth and I can give them to the honourable senator chapter and verse, but I did not see this particular article. All of the issues mentioned in that question arise from that article and deserve a full and thorough answer. I will put the matter on notice and provide the honourable senator with one.

—Does the Minister for Resources agree with the article in the Canberra Times on 16 April 1988 by Keith Scott that the Minister and the Prime Minister are of a different view with regard to the allegations by Senator Sanders over Australian uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. As a matter of fact, I bought a copy of the Canberra Times on Saturday morning at the Red Hill shops. Much to my surprise on its front page it carried an article headed `Uranium: Hawke in new fight'. I read in subsequent paragraphs after that lead that apparently there is some difference between me and the Prime Minister on the subject. I can say categorically that there is no difference between me and the Prime Minister on the subject. It seems that a journalist decided to write that the Prime Minister had dismissed fresh allegations and make it appear as if allegations that I had not dealt with were dismissed. The article stated that Mr Hawke's comments:

ANSWER.PARA: contrast with those of the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook.
The article continued:
Mr Hawke said yesterday that there `doesn't seem to be anything in these new allegations'.

Senators in this place who listened to my answers to questions on 16 March from Senator Wood, on 17 March from Senator Sanders and on 22 March from Senator Wood will know that a consistent theme in all my answers on all those occasions was that the original source documents on the allegation about flag swaps of Australian origin uranium were several articles in January and February in the German magazine Der Spiegel; that we had obtained that magazine, translated it into English and found a confused series of contending and misunderstanding issues; that we had found that what had been said in the European Parliament and billed as a separate round of allegations seemed to us to relate to the Der Spiegel ones. That is true also of what Australian politicians have alleged. On that basis `no fresh allegations' is an accurate description.

The second part of the article was that the Prime Minister seems to have dismissed the allegations. Honourable senators will know that that is consistent with my answers on those occasions, too. I have used words to the effect that on advice to us from our officers the integrity of Australian safeguards is intact, so there is consistency on that point.

On the third point the Prime Minister said-and if anyone wishes to read the full transcript of what the Prime Minister said it will be seen that there was selective quoting from what he said in a doorstop interview here in Parliament House and in a bookshop doorstop interview in Sydney on Friday-that we are, of course, investigating all the allegations to give a full statement on them and that if anyone has any information he wishes to bring forward to include in that investigation, we shall include it and put down a reply to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that there would be no problems.

—I say to Senator Walters, who seems to have a fascination with this subject, that we will put down a reply to it this week. There should be a clear distinction in the minds of honourable senators between an allegation and a fact. Some people who have made allegations choose to describe what they say as fact and some journalists choose to report what they then say as if they are facts. We have consistently categorised allegations based on the Der Spiegel articles as allegations. When honourable senators see our statement later in the week dealing methodically with each of them, they will come to appreciate that the allegations cannot be described as fact.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has his attention been drawn to a poll in a Canberra newspaper in which some 77 per cent of over 2,500 respondents expressed opposition to a proposed casino development in Canberra? I ask whether the Minister's attention been drawn to the recommendations of the board of inquiry into casinos in the State of Victoria, which-and I quote the Victorian Attorney-General:

QUESTION.PARA: recommended that casinos should not be permitted in Victoria . . . casinos of whatever variety.

What steps would the Minister consider taking to prevent the involvement of organised crime in a proposed Canberra casino? What steps would the Minister take to prevent the stimulation of casino gambling among the population of Canberra? Can the Minister demonstrate that there is a genuine popular demand for a casino in Canberra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government took a decision on a casino for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) some time ago. It should be noted that the total development involves high quality hotel accommodation, retail and other entertainment facilities. The total investment in the project would be in the order of $300m. It would involve thousands of jobs in the construction phase and over 1,000 permanent jobs once completed. A new Canberra theatre and library would be funded from the payment made by the developer of the site. In short, the Government considers that Canberra cannot afford to reject the proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has indicated that it intends to plan this development in a responsible manner. We have commissioned an independent study of the social impact of the casino in the Australian Capital Territory. Recently I gave some details of it in this place. The study will consider the adequacy of the proposed casino control legislation and the likely impact of the casino on gambling activity in the Australian Capital Territory. Part of the study will involve examining measures to prevent the involvement of organised crime. The casino control ordinance will determine the operation of the casino and exclude undesirable elements. The terms of reference for the study require it to have regard to the experience of casinos in other States and reports from other inquiries, such as the one referred to in the question from the Victorian Government. The study is advertising publicly for submissions and will conduct public consultations.

The Government is aware of the poll to which Senator Jenkins referred from the Canberra Chronicle. The results of any poll are always interesting, but one must read them in conjunction with a reading of the methodology adopted in the poll. In this case that involved asking people interested to send in coupons-hardly what any of us would consider the best way of conducting a poll into anything. I have some doubt whether that poll would accurately reflect in total the views of the local community. Having said that, I stress that the Government obviously is aware of community concern about the impact of a casino in the ACT. We are conducting a social impact study for that very reason. The Government hopes that ACT residents will take the opportunity the study provides to express their views on any local problems they see emerging.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a supplementary question. Is the Minister suggesting that the citizens of Canberra can have a new theatre and library only on the proceeds of a casino?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that if the residents of the Australian Capital Territory want a new theatre and a library, they would get it much more quickly if the casino were approved and payments from the casino operators were being made.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA: TIME CHARGED LOCAL CALLS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Following my question last Friday, when I asked the Minister to explain how Telecom spent $608,900 on its analysis of the proposal to time charge for local calls, I draw the Minister's attention to a full page advertisement placed by Telecom in the House Magazine-Volume 6, No. 29 of 9-16 December 1987-a magazine produced for senators and members. The advertisement lauds the commitment of Telecom to provide telephone services in remote areas of outback Australia and states:

QUESTION.PARA: Recently the six inhabitants of William Creek, reputedly Australia's smallest town, celebrated the arrival of the world's loneliest phone box. This project alone cost Telecom 1.6 million dollars.
Before the program is completed we'll spend closer to 500 million dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to that speech in a day or two when I obtain further information.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Minister seen the recent brochures and pamphlets put out by the Women's Sport Promotions Unit and launched late last year by Minister John Brown? Can the Minister say whether the Women's Sport Promotion Unit and the national policy for women in sport are receiving wide recognition and whether he will take any further steps to ensure full implementation of that policy? Finally, has the Government any role to play in reviewing the Olympic Games selectors' decision not to choose any women rowers, despite evidence of inaccurate timing of their races?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to place on record the Government's position on this issue. From the start it is important to recognise that for too long women have faced barriers which have restrained them from deriving the full benefits available through involvement in sport. Two important points need to be acknowledged. First, in December 1987 the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) national policy and plan for women in sport was announced. The importance of this document can be gauged from the fact that demand for the copies has been so great that it has exceeded supply and it is already into a second print run. I think that every member of parliament has been provided with a copy of that document.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point relates to the establishment of the Women's Sport Promotion Unit. The ASC has provided staffing and initial funding of $50,000 for this financial year. A brochure outlining the Unit's brief has been printed and I have instructed the ASC to provide a copy to all members and senators. The main objectives of the Women's Sport Promotion Unit are to promote and raise awareness of the involvement of women in sport, to encourage and increase participation, conduct research and provide greater information about the issues affecting women in sport, and to implement the ASC's national policy on women in sport. The Government is fully committed to that issue and the Unit's operations will be given priority in subsequent financial years. I ask that honourable senators also note the bipartisan nature of support for those initiatives.

In respect of the honourable senator's last question about women rowers, I think two points should be made. The first is that evidence about whether the timing of their efforts was correct is being looked at. I am certainly prepared to write to the national rowing body if I feel that there is anything in that evidence. The main point to make is that it has never been the role-nor should it ever be the role-of the Minister for sport to choose the team to go to any given Olympics. That must be the role of sporting bodies, and I do not intend to usurp that role. Occasionally the Minister probably has an opportunity to nudge, but there is very little beyond that. I never try to accrue power, as you are well and truly aware, Mr President, and I will not do so on this occasion either.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: — Last Friday Senator Aulich asked me a question about a letter in the Australian Financial Review of 12 April relating to cement production. I began to answer the question but was interrupted by the conclusion of Question Time. I add to that answer the following matters. In recent months unions have lobbied the Government, as have cement companies, not in search of traditional protection but for the implementation of a total ban on cement imports into Australia. The Government will not do that, and I have informed the industry of that decision on at least four occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point that that request for a ban on cement imports into Australia comes at a time when between 1 and 2 per cent of the cement used in Australia is imported. Of course the National Party Government in Queensland has announced a ban on imports into that State, but that is its business and the Federal Government will not follow that course. The fact that cement imports are so small in the total scheme of things is not to say that there could never be a problem with unfair competition from imports. I note that Japan, for example, recently has had exports of 14 million tonnes annually and Korea has had a big increase in the export of cement and there are concerns in the Australian industry about dumping. If that occurs and a dumping complaint is properly made, it will be dealt with by the Australian Customs Service in the normal way.

Allegations of dumping cannot be relied on. Allegations are insufficient as far as the Government is concerned-dumping must be proved. Further, people in the cement industry are saying that the experience in the United States of America suggests that Australia will be subjected to import penetration by foreign cement manufacturers. Certainly there has been a big rise in cement imports into the USA in search of a very strong market there. Of course, there were no attempts by the United States producers to prevent those imports. Many of the United States producers were clearly uncompetitive. I think the lessons of the United States industry indicate essentially that steps should be taken to ensure that the Australian industry is more competitive, is working for greater efficiency, and is organised to act quickly against dumping if it occurs. The industry here has been slow to argue its case to Customs in relation to dumping. There seems to be little enthusiasm at the present time to become more competitive. I have told the industry that the Government will do everything it can to process the industry's anti-dumping case as quickly as possible. I have asked the Bureau of Industry Economics to conduct a study on the current state of the industry, and we have also established a liaison committee to monitor and review these reports.

In relation to that last matter, nearly a month after its announcement of that initiative the industry has still not nominated representatives. There is a second complaint about that which I do not need to deal with during Question Time. Undoubtedly the Australian cement industry is apprehensive about imports, but there must be something more than apprehension to justify some of the conduct which has occurred. It seems to me a particularly unfortunate use of the work force by companies in the industry to encourage activities in pursuit of a campaign which is ultimately designed to protect the vested interests of the companies concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 14 April Senator Panizza asked me a question about the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. It is now possible for me to add to the answer that I gave on that occasion. I have spoken to Minister Kerin about the issues raised by Senator Panizza. He has asked me to say that the issues raised by the report are both complex and comprehensive and will require detailed consideration by a range of authorities. To assist informed discussion, the Government has appointed the former commissioner who conducted the Royal Commission, Mr Jim McColl, as a consultant to advise interested parties on the recommendations in the report and the rationale behind them. Mr McColl is due to meet with national growers and employees' representatives later this month, and the Government will need to consult with the State governments and other interested parties in determining its response to the Commission's report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question relating to the amount of fuel tax revenue spent on improving roads, at which time I undertook to provide the honourable senator with a detailed reply, which I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

The increases in fuel taxes since 1984-85 have occurred for macro-economic reasons. Under the Import Parity Pricing Scheme the 1986 fall in the international price of crude oil had the potential to severely erode general revenue raised by the crude oil levy. The Government therefore decided to increase the excise component in the price of petrol and diesel in order to protect its revenue base. This adjustment to fuel excise was made in such a way as to preserve overall revenue neutrality, but resulted in a significantly higher level of fuel excise collections in 1985-86 and 1986-87. If this action had not been taken as crude oil prices fell, the Government would have needed to increase taxation in other areas or make significant cuts to a wide range of expenditure activities.

For budgetary reasons the Government has found it necessary to restrict its outlays on roads, as it has in other areas of Federal expenditure. It is misleading, however, to make comparisons based solely on the proportion of excise returned to roads.

Issues relating to the ear-marking of a proportion of fuel excise to roads are being considered by the Government as part of its review of Federal road funding arrangements to replace the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program from the beginning of next year.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Vanstone proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to structure or administer the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse so as to permit the successful achievement of its goals which are shared by all Australians.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of public importance. When one considers the attitudes that we find in the community today and the apprehension that parents feel as to whether their children will be caught by the drug menace-when one looks at what is happening-one comes to the conclusion that this Government has failed to structure or administer the National Campaign against Drug Abuse so as to permit the successful achievement of its goals, which are shared by all Australians. I note that the Government considers this such an important matter that it is not even prepared to put forward a Minister to defend its record in terms of administering and controlling the structure of the campaign! Instead, we have a backbencher-a very competent backbencher, I admit. Nonetheless no Minister is prepared to come into this chamber and defend the Government's record in relation to this campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Liberal Party Federal Council meeting one weekend ago my Leader, John Howard, said:

Nothing strikes more terror into the hearts of parents than the fear that their children will fall prey to drug abuse. No family and no child-irrespective of their background-is insulated from the danger of drugs. The drug menace represents one of the most insidious threats to the social fabric of this country. It is an issue which for my part transcends partisan politics. The challenge we face is an immediate one, demanding action in a co-ordinated and genuinely bipartisan manner.

It is in that spirit that this matter is brought on today. After all, consideration of something in a bipartisan manner does not mean that one sits back and accepts everything that the Government does on a particular project. Quite the opposite; it means that, with all the resources at hand, one debates a matter as openly and publicly as possible to ensure that the common goals are achieved. I personally hold little hope that the Government will accept my Leader's offer, because this publicity machine for the beleaguered Minister Blewett is not something that he or the Government has any intention of giving away, and they have no intention of being deflected from that path.

I mentioned earlier that this matter touched all Australians, and I referred to some quotes detailing the concerns that parents have; but, of course, it is not only parents. One must consider the young children, perhaps too young to be listening to this debate, who go to school hoping that no one will notice the bruises on their bodies, terrified at having to lie yet again to cover up for the fact that the night before mum or dad, with a few drinks under their belt, beat them up; and those same kids who go home on the bus with somewhat of a dark cloud hanging over them hoping that it will not happen again tonight.

One thinks of the schoolchildren old enough to be listening to this debate who really need a mother or father who is interested in helping them with their homework and having some discussions about the problems they have in facing the teenage years. Yet they know that just that one extra tranquilliser that has been popped in makes any real discussion with their mother not a high probability. Parents are concerned not only that their children will fall prey to the drug menace but also that perhaps their children on the way home from university or school will be cleaned up by someone driving on the road, a person with far too much alcohol in the blood in charge of a vehicle on the road. One thinks of the mother who hopes that her daughter will take a rightful place in the community, given the changing social expectations of women, only to see that daughter with falling grades at university or at school and with a falling self-respect. One thinks of the father who hopes that his son will achieve far greater things than he was able to but who sees a boy whose only ambition is nothing more than the next fix.

Leaving the matter of the mother and the father and the children and the implications that it has for them, one next considers the employers of Australia, faced with a person who has been a good employee but who, due either to family stress or to stress at work, takes to alcohol or some form of drug abuse. An employer is then put in the position of deciding whether to `let the person go' or to try to see that person through the stress period. All these people are concerned with this debate and what we have to say.

It is a shared goal to have healthier Australians of all age groups and of both sexes, with an ever-decreasing dependence on drugs and alcohol. That is a shared goal. However, we would choose a different path towards that goal from that chosen by the Government. The Government chose to start with a gigantic media launch which really amounted to advertising its intention to do something about the drug problem in Australia but which did not actually achieve anything. People were making jokes about the drug offensive being called the `drug expensive'. When one thinks back to when that campaign was first launched, one thinks of the concept of a Federal government running round the country throwing glossy booklets into people's backyards, and not even managing that task properly, which was an embarrassment.

As to my comment about the Government not even managing that task properly, some people may not remember that some of the drug offensive leaflets that were hurled over the front and back fences had in them an advertisement for the `cannabis defensive' a National Organisation for Reform of Marihuana Laws-NORML-initiative, with little words that said, `Do you think this $100m drug campaign is offensive?'. The Government could not even manage to deliver the booklets in the first place without their being interfered with. Other booklets had the results of the Australian smoking survey inserted in them. So, that is the first point: a general, broad media campaign advertising basically the intention rather than getting to the substance of the matter is not something that the coalition parties would have done. I note that Senator Bolkus-now Minister Bolkus-said when he was last in New York:
Expensive PR campaigns are not the answer. The US Government is spending millions on relatively ineffectual drug education programs.

One would think that, if a member of the Government is prepared to acknowledge that expensive public relations (PR) campaigns are not the way to go, it would have by now reconsidered its approach. However, apparently this has not yet happened.

Not only did people find the general concept of a PR launch offensive-not wishing to use a pun-but some of the contents of that campaign were unsatisfactory. A Ms Mary Benson, head of a self-help group for women alcoholics, said:
The Government leaflet which was distributed to about five million homes portrayed girls who drank as cheap in the eyes of boys. They were regarded as real push-overs and an embarrassment.

What Ms Benson was saying was that hundreds of thousands of alcoholic women were ashamed to seek treatment because of the stereotype of drunk women as sluts. Her comments on the inclusion of that sort of terminology in this broad campaign were as follows:
This has destroyed the work we have been doing for 10 years.

On the ground, grassroots drug workers in many States ask, `Why focus on hard drugs? Why not focus on the legal drugs which are the real killers?'. We have yet to have an argument from the Government indicating why it selected the hard drugs to start this campaign with. A Ms Payne from the Independent Association for Recovery from Alcoholism said:

The new drug offensive follows in the footsteps of what has happened in NSW. Front line troops, the health workers with long experience in dealing directly with drug affected people, are almost entirely excluded from the policy and planning level.

This is not the way to go. If the Government is going to have a big PR campaign the very least it can do is get the information in it right. Since drug abuse is such an important matter, it seems trite to raise a political point but I recall asking then Senator Ryan when she was the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women what she thought about the comments in the drug offensive leaflet Boys on Girls on Drugs. She admitted that she had not been consulted about using that type of terminology. The leaflet having been put out by a government that says it is anti-sexist, she was concerned and said she would raise the matter with those responsible for that campaign. Yet some alcohol campaign advertisements which were released recently follow the same lines. In summary on that point, suffice it to say we would not have gone that way and any PR campaign we would have gone into certainly would not have made those mistakes. We would have consulted with the people on the ground and tried to address the real issues rather than advertising to the community that we had a concern.

The reason that the PR campaign was so badly placed and that the campaign has been so poorly co-ordinated since then is the lack of adequate research. I draw the Government's attention to the comments in Trends and Issues, No. 1, July 1986, of the Australian Institute of Criminology. This is what it had to say about the formulation of this campaign:

It remains, however, somewhat surprising that this country could launch a $100m National Campaign Against Drug Abuse and that so many extra resources and powers should be granted to law enforcement bodies in the absence of any real knowledge of the size of the illegal drug problem.
Statistics on Drug Abuse in Australia of 1986, produced by the Commonwealth Department of Health, as it was then, says:
Available information on the extent and patterns of drug use is quite limited, particularly concerning the illegal use of drugs and the use of volatile substances.

In summary, the evidence indicates that alcohol, tobacco, analgesics and cannabis are used more commonly than any other drugs and that the use of alcohol, analgesics and cannabis by the young is increasing. The use of most drugs by adults tends to be decreasing.

What that says is that the whole initial focus of this campaign was on the wrong foot. The whole focus was on the hard, illicit drugs and it has only just started to shift to the licit ones with the recent launch of the alcohol campaign. Just to ensure that people understand that these are not the views of an opposition seeking to make capital out of some high profile Government activity, let me quote from Ian Dobinson from the New South Wales Bureau of Crime Statistics and Research, which is in the New South Wales Attorney-General's Department. He said:

My criticism of the campaign is that there is no way we will be able to say whether or not it has been effective. We don't know what the situation is now. We don't have the information or the capability of determining that. The basic ethnographic research has not been done.
The author of the article titled `Why the Drug Offensive may fail' has this to say:
The drug offensive has been politically initiated and politically timetabled.
It appears to have been trapped into over-hasty action on insufficient research . . .
There have been claims that health professionals have not been adequately consulted.
It was very rushed.

I could go on. Article after article confirms the view that we put. Inadequate research was done. If the appropriate research had been done the Government would have been able more properly to target its initial campaign and the campaigns that followed. If it had done that appropriate research it would have understood the problems in having a national campaign against drug abuse in which it tries to push national priorities onto States when those priorities were not necessarily reflected on a State by State basis. The Chairman of the South Australian Drug and Alcohol Services Council, Graham Forbes, said:
The smallest States are taking a different approach. We want to see that the real issues are focused upon.

That is what the coalition wants to see-the real issues in drug abuse focused on, not the high profile heroin addict issues affecting a smaller proportion of the community. So much of the other drug abuse that is going on in the community appears to be, by and large, being ignored in the high profile national aspect of this campaign. This is an appropriate place to say that it is not being ignored by the States-not at all-but it is being ignored by the national contribution to this campaign. Plenty of research has been done to indicate that the Government is going the wrong way. The campaign against drug abuse bureaucracy will tell us that the research was done, but it is not appropriate to address a campaign on the prejudices of the population. A campaign needs to be directed to the real problems and not the public perceptions of them.

I turn to State co-operation. We remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) got into government saying this was going to be a consensus government. One does not need to point out how obviously untrue that is. This was going to be a campaign with a large national element and co-operation between the States. The South Australians believe that South Australia should devote the resources that they have to helping to prevent another Kings Cross problem by helping young people at risk before they go onto hard drugs rather than promoting a problem that does not really exist there yet. A newspaper article reports that the Victorians say:

NCADA is inspired more by politics than by community needs. ``It has attended far more to the political imperatives than welfare imperatives. The whole idea of a national campaign itself contradicts national guidelines on drug programs''.

The problem being raised by the States is that some of them do not have the same problems that Sydney has. My State does not have a Kings Cross with heroin addicts falling about in the back streets. We want to concentrate on other problems. To have a national campaign is fine, provided that national campaign works with the States on such an important matter, takes into account the State differences and works on thorough research to start with.

I mentioned earlier that the recent launch of the alcohol campaign contained some advertisements carrying on the problems that had been started in earlier sections of the campaign; namely, the use of sexist stereotypes. But the problems have been much bigger than that. To start with, the timing of the alcohol campaign was changed simply to suit the New South Wales election, not that it did the Australian Labor Party much good. Consternation has been raised over these advertisements. As a result, I wrote to John Loy, the campaign manager, and asked about the basis on which this campaign was launched. I asked for the research material so that the coalition could, in a bipartisan way, assess whether the Government was going the right way. The letter I got back thanked me for my original letter and said that the Minister for Community Services and Health had agreed that the campaign material should be published as soon as possible and as soon as it was public I could have it. I do not regard that as a bipartisan approach to a campaign. When the Opposition coalition seeks to get information and to work with the Government and to find out whether it has done the right thing before criticising it publicly it is told that it can wait until the matter becomes public.

Last but not least, let me deal with the matter of women. I sit here day after day listening to Senator Reynolds explaining in dulcet tones that her Government cares about women. I have seen much publicity given to the Government's research into domestic violence. I simply make the point that one does not need yet another survey from the Office of the Status of Women to see the role that alcohol plays in domestic violence. Yet nowhere in this alcohol campaign has consideration been given to the role of alcohol in domestic violence. I would very much like to know-perhaps Senator Giles or Senator Zakharov can tell us later in the debate-what advice the Office of the Status of Women offered the Government on the role of alcohol in domestic violence and the obvious importance that has to women and children who are affected by that violence.

There is an additional point. I made the point in the very beginning that we believe that this campaign has gone the wrong way because it concentrated initially on the illicit drugs and left, until the start of the alcohol campaign, the licit drugs, the real problems, up to the States. It has not done much. The States have done something. My State recently started a very good campaign. I think it is called `This Women is now in Charge'. New South Wales, Senator Puplick's State, has done something about it-but not the Federal Government.

Again, I would be interested to know what advice the Office of the Status of Women offered this Government in terms of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse. It has a predetermination to advertise its intention rather than to get at the real problems of drug abuse, which are, as I have said, with the licit drugs more so than the illicit drugs.

I look forward to hearing what Senator Collins has to say about what the Government will now do to get the campaign against drug abuse back on the right track and to get appropriate consultation with the States and some decent research on which to base the future of the campaign.

—In response to that interjection I must say that I have considerable sympathy for Senator Baume's views on drugs. I have read widely what Senator Baume has said. I am not sure-I am prepared to be persuaded-whether going along the route of loosening controls over drugs simply because we are conscious of the fact that licit drugs are being abused even more is necessarily the way to go. SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take up one specific point. In fact, she issued a Press statement in which she made the accusation that the launch of the alcohol campaign was a political stunt. I quote from her Press release:
The launch this morning of the campaign against alcohol abuse shows that Labor hijacked the campaign to suit the publicity needs of the ailing Unsworth Government.

The timing and preparation of the launch and campaign were rushed so as to allow the New South Wales Premier to launch the New South Wales section of the campaign at the Southern Cross, Goulburn Street, Sydney on the last Sunday before the New South Wales State election.
She went on to say, as the basis for her charge:
Originally there was to be a staggered launch of the advertisements in each State.

The problem is that Senate Vanstone's political attack on the program was utterly wrong. Seeing that it has not been done before, I will correct the record at this stage. It was never planned to have a staggered launch for the campaign. In fact in 1987 the national Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy resolved that a media campaign addressing the issue of alcohol abuse be run simultaneously in all States and Territories, and that the campaign should commence as soon as appropriate. At a meeting on 17 November 1987 of the Commonwealth-State project management group-not the New South Wales Labor Party-which was oversighting the campaign, a timetable leading to the launch on 6 March 1988 was circulated.
