SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that we have in the gallery this afternoon a number of young people, and I hope they will stay for a while. Rather than attack the Government or the Opposition on this matter, I make a plea-I guess this is part of what Senator Vanstone had to say-for a much greater emphasis on the abuse of licit drugs, and notably tobacco because undoubtedly tobacco is the drug which creates more health problems and more deaths in Australia than any other. Indeed, the initial pamphlet put out by the Commonwealth Government to every Australian household indicates that 80 per cent of drug related deaths in Australia involve the use of tobacco. The evidence is quite clear that any smoking, even passive smoking-sidestream smoking, living in a smoking atmosphere where one does not smoke but one's spouse does-carries a health risk. The pamphlet points out that some 10 per cent of drug related deaths and illnesses involve alcohol, only 2 per cent involve hard drugs and the remainder involve many of those drugs which Senator Vanstone has mentioned-sedatives, tranquillisers, and other drugs of that sort.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose to the extent that I have a criticism of the program so far it is that initially there has been an overemphasis on a small part of the problem-namely, the abuse of hard drugs-and only more recently have we seen a shift in the program towards a concern for the abuse of alcohol. But even alcohol is only a minor part of the problem. By comparison, if 80 per cent of drug related deaths are due to tobacco, a 2 1/2 per cent reduction in that section of the problem would more than exceed all of the deaths and ill effects related to the abuse of hard drugs. So I guess this afternoon I want to make the plea that there be from here on in a far greater emphasis on all aspects of the use of tobacco and tobacco products, and that the Federal Government do a number of things to control that aspect not only within the drug offensive, as such, but also by way of taxation and a number of other issues which I shall mention. As far as I am aware-and Senator Collins has mentioned this-the only action the Federal Government has taken in relation to tobacco use is to ban smoking on flights and interstate coaches. I do not think any other specific action has been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —And office buildings.
—Certainly there have been moves in that direction as far as the Public Service is concerned.
—Starting with the Department of Health.

—Starting with the Department of Health, as Senator Baume says. In Australia each year, and I have reminded the Senate of this before, 23,000 deaths result from the consumption of tobacco and tobacco products-63 deaths a day, far more people than are sitting in this chamber at present. This figure is far greater than that for any other area of drug abuse. There are a number of diseases related to tobacco and tobacco products. We are all aware that lung cancer is one, and that is indeed serious because I believe that still, even with the best treatment, 95 per cent of lung cancers eventually prove to be fatal.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have already mentioned, not only are smokers subject to an increased risk of lung cancer; non-smokers who inhabit smokey rooms are also subject to an increased risk. Professor Dole, from Oxford, who I think is recognised as the world's leading epidemiologist, indicated when he was in Australia that there was an increase of some 25 per cent in the risk of a person developing lung cancer if his or her spouse smoked. We are talking not only about lung cancer. There is an increased risk of bladder cancer. We now know from testing that cancer-causing agents are absorbed through the lungs and get into the circulation. They are circulated through the body and are excreted in the urine. They can be detected in the urine, so not surprisingly we know there is an increased risk of bladder cancer, an increased risk of bowel cancer, and to a lesser extent cancers elsewhere in the body.

There is, of course, an effect on the unborn if a woman chooses to smoke during pregnancy. It is well known that children of smoking mothers are more likely to be born undersized or premature and be subject to all the consequences of that condition. Perhaps less well known is that the infants of smoking fathers are more likely to be aborted or to be born with birth defects. The reason for this is quite clear. Most of the carcinogenic substances which we know occur in tobacco smoke are also mutagenic, and quite clearly smoking by the father is capable of causing mutations in the sperm which either in that generation or in later generations can produce defects in the offspring. Even beyond birth we have to consider the effect of smoking on children. The statistics are quite clear: the children of smoking parents are more likely themselves to become smokers.

I turn to a few other diseases. Chronic bronchitis is a serious problem, ultimately leading in many cases to emphysema, severe shortness of breath, and an inability to work. Arterial diseases, such as thromboangiitis obliterans, or Buerger's disease, affect a large number of people. I think most of us have seen people who get severe cramps in their legs, and some of us will have seen those who eventually have had to have limbs amputated as a consequence of the exacerbation of this disease. Of course coronary heart disease is also more common among smokers. Smoking is responsible for a quite large proportion of the deaths and illnesses related to coronary heart disease and its consequences. Perhaps less well recognised is the fact that most of the diseases associated with the ageing process are more common in those who smoke. All the diseases which one associates with the ageing process are more likely to come on at an earlier age in a smoker. Finally, we are also aware that smoking synergises the ill effects of exposure to many other substances. Two well known ones are asbestos and uranium mining. The health effects on those who are exposed to radioactive particles or to asbestos and who are also smokers are far more marked and far more serious.

I believe that the Government has done very little to stem the tide of ill health related to this most serious drug addiction, which has been called this afternoon a licit drug. But, more than this, I think it has actively taken measures to defeat some of the things which have been done to tackle this problem. In October last year I attempted to move in this chamber that the advertising of tobacco products be no longer tax deductible. I did this on the grounds that companies pay tax at the rate of roughly 50 per cent, so roughly 50 per cent of the cost of advertising tobacco products comes from general tax revenue. It is avoided tax. I pointed out-I see Senator Collins nodding his head on the other side of the chamber-that political advertising by the tobacco companies has also been indulged in, particularly in Victoria and South Australia, and that political advertising to defeat State legislation in relation to tobacco consumption remains tax deductible. The Federal Government, through its tax policy, is allowing the continuation of this form of advertising, which is designed to defeat the efforts by the forces attempting to overcome this most serious problem. It is worth noting in passing at this point that the cost of tobacco advertising is estimated to be between $100m and $150m a year. In terms of revenue alone, removing the tax deductibility of tobacco advertising would bring in further revenue of between $50 and $75m.

It should be noted that when I raised this matter in debate on a taxation Bill last year I moved an amendment that was defeated by the combined opposition of both the Government and the Opposition. I note that Senator Peter Baume is to speak after me. Last year, very wisely and bravely, I thought, he absented himself from the chamber and sat in the gallery while the vote was being taken. It is not just the health effects and the financial costs in those forms which are of significance. In 1981-82 the Medical Journal of Australia estimated that the direct dollar costs of smoking and the ill health and deaths associated with it were roughly $1 billion per year-about $400m in the cost of hospital beds and care, $250m associated with deaths and about $350m in social costs related to lost wages and lost productivity. It is worth making the point that those costs have almost certainly risen at least 50 per cent to 100 per cent by now. In the current year, 1987-88, it is estimated that Federal revenue from tobacco and tobacco products will be about $1.068 billion; in other words, the dollar costs of ill health and deaths related to the consumption of tobacco far exceeds the revenue which the Federal Government derives from that source.

I notice that the Government actually assists the tobacco industry. The tobacco companies that buy 50 per cent of their leaf from Australian growers get a concessional duty rate on imported leaf. That is direct financial assistance to the tobacco product manufacturers. Moreover, the price of leaf is fixed by a Government-backed marketing authority. In a time of quite considerable government deregulation, we find that the tobacco industry remains very highly regulated. Indeed, the tobacco industry is the most protected of all Australian agricultural industries. Assistance in 1983-84 was well over 100 per cent against an average of 11 per cent for all agricultural industries. This Government has set up the Tobacco Research Council. I have before me the annual report of the Tobacco Research Council for 1986-87. The purpose of the establishment of this Council was, among other things:
increasing the commercial returns to industry members and to the community in general by improving the production . . . of tobacco.

We find that the research objectives are: new tobacco cultivars which maintain high yields with enhanced leaf quality, including smokeability; new cultivars with desirable agronomic characters; emergent pest, disease and weed control; plant nutrition to enhance leaf quality; improved soil and land management; better farm production and mechanisation; and the development of the professional competence and skills of personnel involved in the tobacco research program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is often asserted that we are in a war against drug abuse. That is fair enough, but we are all entitled to know, if we are engaged in such a war, who is the enemy, who are our allies, what are the goals we are pursuing, what is winning this drug war and what is losing it. Many speakers have implied some answers. I pay tribute to some of the speakers who have preceded me for what I think is a civilised and very reasonable debate, but the answers which come out remain implicit; they are never made quite clear. They have not been clarified, just as the values underlying most approaches to drug campaigns remain unstated most of the time. Since none of these questions have clear public answers, is it any wonder that we, with all our good intentions, do so badly in dealing with drugs?

SPEECH.PARA: Who are the enemies? Lawyers and enforcement authorities will tell us that the enemies are those who are engaged in the distribution of substances whose use is illegal in Australia. They then design strategies, taken up by governments, which are directed against the supplies and the suppliers of these drugs. The people who design these programs forget that, in the way of classic market operations, there is demand and supply-suppliers bringing the drugs onto the market and users willing and ready to trade, to pay the price to obtain the drugs. If we are to interrupt this process and do it successfully as a nation, we need to interrupt both demand and supply, not to concentrate on the supply side alone. Our policies, our strategies and our campaigns virtually ignore demand. Our strategies and our campaigns virtually ignore demand. Our strategies seek to prevent the production of certain substances which we have designated as illegal, and they fail to prevent that production. Our strategies seek to prevent the importation of substances which we have determined to be illegal, and they fail to prevent that importation. Our policies seek to prevent the distribution of illegal substances, and they fail to prevent that distribution. They seek to prevent the sale of substances which we determine to be illegal, and they fail to prevent the sale of those substances. Our policies seek to prevent the use of the substances, and they fail to do that too.

If the dealers are not the enemy, perhaps the substances themselves are the enemy. Heroin, the other opiates, morphia and the other narcotics, properly used, are, of course, a godsend for those with intolerable pain. Making heroin illegal has certainly made it unavailable for those with intolerable pain and suffering, but it has left it readily available in Kings Cross in my city on the illegal market.

Who are our allies in this so-called drug war? We are told that they are our police, our doctors, our Australian Customs Service and so on. We are told that they are our prisons, our courts, our judges and our magistrates. But our doctors and therapists have very little success with users, many of whom do not regard themselves as ill or in any need of treatment and may enter a program simply as a lesser evil than going to gaol. That is why I asked Senator Collins whether the programs work, because the figures are depressing. They generally do not seem to work. Today it is probably easier to get illegal drugs inside our prisons than it is to get them outside our prisons. Indeed, the new Minister for prisons in New South Wales announced yesterday that there would be routine spot urine checks of prisoners to try to find out which of them are using drugs. I will tell him now that that is not going to work either.

Some of the police throughout Australia have become deeply involved as participants in the game rather than as allies and protectors of the public good. There is more money to be made by corrupt behaviour by a tiny minority of officials than they can ever hope for from their pay or superannuation. Mr Acting Deputy President, you and I come from the same State. We know of Tim Bristow and his associates, to give one example. We have heard of Murray Riley. We have heard of Murray Farquhar. We have heard of the Cessna-Milner case. We have heard of the police who ran dead for almost a decade on the murder of Donald Mackay. We have heard of the Trimbole networks, and so on. Let me tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that my children and my children's generation hold the police in my State in contempt. They believe that the police are deeply and systematically corrupt, and they tell me so. How tragic it is that this should be the case. Yes, there are corrupt officials. They are only a minority, but those corrupt officials can prosper for only one reason, and that is because of laws we have made and the prohibition strategies we have told those officials to enforce on our behalf.

What are our goals for drug use? Is our goal to produce a drug-free society, a drug abstinent society? If so, it would be the first such society in history. That has never been the stated goal of any drug initiative in Australia. The problem is that we in this country are two-faced about drugs. We suffer from national hypocrisy in this matter. As Senator Coulter has said, we differentiate between substances, some illegal and some `okay'. Some are illegal and not acceptable; some are legal and quite okay. We act as if some drugs are of themselves inherently evil, that the substance is inherently evil, instead of acknowledging that the drugs themselves are instruments only and that abuse arises from the ways in which drugs are used by human beings. Heroin and morphia, as I said earlier, give pain relief as well as causing addiction. Marijhuana can relieve glaucoma and some of the side effects of cancer therapy at the same time as it can cause motor vehicle crashes. Alcohol serves valued social purposes as well as causing personal and family misery. I could go on and give other examples.

Apart from the fact that the divisions between what is illegal and what is legal are quite arbitrary-morphia was legal in this country into this century-let us for one moment reflect on some figures which have already been given to us, certainly by Senator Coulter and I think by Senator Collins too. From Department of Community Services and Health figures we know that drug related deaths in this decade were just under one-fifth of all the deaths recorded. We know that, of the drug related deaths, those due to alcohol and tobacco made up 97 out of every 100 deaths; only three out of every 100 were due to all other drugs, that is, deliberate and accidental poisonings, self-administered poisonings, therapeutic drugs and illicit or illegal drugs.

Deaths from opiates are serious, and every death is a personal and family tragedy somewhere. But, as Senator Coulter has said, so is every death from tobacco and so is every victim of a drunk driver. Why is it that the significance of these mortality figures from our own Department of Community Services and Health is so much avoided when policy making occurs or when national programs are constructed? Why are we so willing to devote major resources to addressing deaths from narcotics, and why are we so willing to ignore the deaths from tobacco, which-my arithmetic may not be perfect-are 40 to 50 times more numerous than deaths from narcotics or from the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, to pick out something else that has a high commitment from government at the moment.

If we are going to talk about a drug war-and that is a ridiculous intellectual construct anyhow-and if we are going to talk about winning or losing such a so-called war, how is it that we can ignore the cause of 97 per cent of the deaths in that drug war and concentrate so much of our effort, resources and rhetoric on the cause of about 1.5 per cent of the deaths? That is what I have against the national campaign against drug abuse. Why do we give knighthoods and respect and honour to the tobacco retailers and send marijuana retailers to prison? Why do we suggest that alcohol barons might make good Prime Ministers, and suggest, as some people do, the return of the death penalty for opiate barons? That occurs. What is the intrinsic difference between one drug and the other?

For one moment let me be a little bit positive. We have to understand some of the dynamics of our present strategy and campaign. We have to understand that we are in a policy situation-I think Senator Collins made this point-where we accept the drug use of the middle-aged and the majority, and we make criminal the drug preferences of the young and the minority. What kind of a country are we? If there is an intrinsic difference between tobacco and heroin in their addictive potential or properties, or in their potential for harm other than the harm caused by the laws we have made, will someone please make that difference clear to me in a reasoned and intellectually acceptable way? No-one has ever done so.

How do we get across some concepts that it is the person, not the substance-perhaps it is the society acting on the person-which causes the problem? Substance use is an expression of dysfunction between a person and that person's environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a symptom.

—That is right, it is a symptom; and laws will not correct that dysfunction or the cause of which that symptom is a manifestation. How do we get it across that attention to poverty, wretchedness, loneliness, hopelessness, alienation and dispossession is needed too? It is a much better strategy for me to be drunk sometimes than for me to face reality which is just too awful.

SPEECH.PARA: How do we get across the point that supply interruption is only one part of any policy and not the policy itself, unless one wants to continue to fail and fail and fail? We need to adjust to our own drug needs and our own drug use; in my case, to my enjoyment of alcohol and caffeine, like Senator Collins, and my intention to continue to use both of them. Only when each of us here understands that we are drug users and we are members of a drug using society, can we with credibility start to consider the drug problems of others. Our approach, the linchpin of which has been supply interdiction backed by the full majesty of the law, has always failed. It failed in the United States of America during the era of alcohol prohibition. It is failing now. It is corrupting and weakening essential organs of our society, and it will continue to fail because of the way we construct it and because of the laws we have made.

We have a problem that we have misstated, misrepresented and therefore that we as a nation have approached in a way which has been doomed to fail from the time that approach was started. That is what is wrong with our national campaign. It is not based on any proper understanding. In some remote parts of Australia the main drug problem is not kava but the inhalation of volatile substances, that is, petrol. Is it seriously suggested by anyone that because young Australians are killing themselves with petrol inhalation we should consider making petrol illegal, or that we should consider that petrol is the problem? Of course it is not the problem. It is the circumstances that are the problem.

The Government could change so much by presenting drug use as it really is, by linking us, the drug using majority, with our fellows whose drug use is dysfunctional and by addressing the underlying social and personal needs that make drugs the preferred option for some otherwise quite rational people. Until and unless we do so, we will continue to promote and to operate within a policy framework, attractive to the majority, politically safe, but doomed never to succeed. We can do better, and the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse should be and should have been the program to help us do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish first to respond to a few statements made by previous speakers. First, I refer to Senator Vanstone's speech in which she talked a lot about the extent of drug abuse. It was because we had some understanding of that extent that we initiated the drug summit, which led to the setting up of the campaign and determined the course of that campaign, but I would make the brief point that domestic violence is not caused by drug abuse. They are both symptoms of other problems. Alcohol, for example, has the effect of reducing inhibition and therefore lowering the threshold of aggressive behaviour, but it does not cause the aggression. Its roots lie elsewhere, and that is what we have to get at.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter spoke very eloquently about the effects of smoking tobacco. I would like to reiterate the point, which was referred to by Senator Collins, that it was our Government which made Australia only the second major country in the world to ban smoking on aircraft-a move which has been widely acclaimed both here and overseas, on safety as well as on health grounds.

I commend Senator Peter Baume for making an excellent speech with which I am almost totally in agreement, particularly when he referred to our hypocrisy about young people. However I disagree with him on one perhaps minor point, that we are giving insufficient attention to demand. Probably we are giving insufficient attention, but we have raised its importance as against the views of those who see enforcement as the answer to the drug problem or non-enforcement as the sole problem. That emphasis has been shifted over the last few years and, I believe, offers a much better hope for the success that I am sure we all seek.
This matter of public importance concerns the alleged failure of the Government:
to structure or administer the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse so as to permit the successful achievement of its goals which are shared by all Australians.

I wish to refer to the wording of the proposition before speaking to the substance. It seems to demonstrate a very simplistic approach when it assumes, firstly, that there is some hope in the short term of successfully achieving all the goals of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse and, secondly, that all Australians share those goals. Does successful achievement mean the elimination of drug abuse in all its forms? If so, I would say that that is clearly impossible in the foreseeable future. People mostly abuse drugs for reasons not directly related to the drug itself, but as a perceived way of coping with problems or with pain, whether that be physical or psychological. Realistically, there is probably no chance of eliminating the causes of drug abuse but we can attack the question of abuse on at least two fronts-education about its risks and effects, and meeting needs in non-drug related ways. But neither of those things can be done quickly. However, what can be done, and is being done, is to educate and inform the community on the extent of the problem, the underlying reasons for it, and of the risks which may follow, for example, from experimentation-although I believe that risk is very much exaggerated-and the modelling effect of the behaviour of parents, teachers and community leaders.

I turn now to the assumption that the goals of the campaign are shared by all Australians. I know of no evidence which backs this assumption, except in a very general way, mainly related to illicit drugs. Certainly those who have a vested interest in increasing the sales of tobacco and alcohol, for example, clearly do not have the same goals as those who would like to see a marked drop in the consumption of those drugs. It is not very long since the mention of nicotine or alcohol in the context of drug abuse brought angry denials from frequent users of those licit drugs. I think that I have given sufficient attention to the terminology of the proposal we are debating. After all, it has the appearance of having been put together and dashed off in a hurry.

I come now to the alleged failure of the Government in the running of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse. I was involved in the educational and counselling aspects of campaigns against drug abuse for a number of years before my election to the Senate, and I now refer to the years of the previous Government. Most of those campaigns-or isolated activities rather than concerted campaigns-were fragmented in the sense that they dealt with a particular drug or a group of drugs, very rarely the legally obtainable ones, and that the methods used were either based on fear or on highly emotive material. A couple of examples stand out in my memory. I remember a speaker coming to the school where I worked and giving information which was demonstrably false, and known to be so by the students-for example, that smoking marijuana will in itself lead to intravenous drug abuse. This line of so-called education was counterproductive in that the students then mistrusted other information from the same source which was factual. In fact they tended to mistrust any other information that was given to them in that area.

The other example was the sort of emotive material, whether in print or on television, which overdramatised the problem. I remember particularly a film on television called No Roses for Michael which raised parents' anxieties in an unproductive way. Similar results flowed from programs which warned parents to watch their children for what could be seen as signs of drug abuse or taking drugs-things such as wanting privacy or stealing money from home. These were seen as signs of possible drug problems, when these behaviours could have arisen from any one of a number of causes. Now, since the initiation of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, we are at least undertaking on a national scale a campaign based on sound research and on the facts of drug abuse which, I had believed, had support across parties and across all States and Territories.

The Federal Government does not structure or administer the campaign. It is a joint initiative by all Australian governments, and the campaign is overseen by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy, which includes Federal, State and Territory health and police Ministers. That council makes the major decisions about the campaign. At its meeting on 6 November 1987, those Ministers approved a Press release from which I would like to quote a couple of excerpts. It states:
The Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy today agreed to a national media campaign on alcohol abuse, particularly targeted at the young, which would begin early next year.
That is what we are now seeing in the media. It notes that:
as part of the co-operative effort in education for prevention of drug abuse, States and Territories were also conducting their own campaigns according to priorities as determined by them.
In their planning for the next triennium Ministers highlighted the need for a new campaign in the area of pharmaceuticals aimed at reducing the misuse of prescription and over-the-counter drugs.
It goes on to deal with other things that were planned and concludes by saying:
Ministers of all State and Territory Governments regardless of political persuasion today reaffirmed the national direction and policy of the Drug Offensive.
That seems to be contrary to the terms of the matter of public importance today. The Press release continued:

They emphasised the solution to drug abuse lies in long-term programs and the continued major commitment of State and Federal resources to ensure that the recommendations of the Drug Summit are maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's consensus.

—Yes, that is consensus. There has been a perception in the community, and even among some senators, that the media campaign is all that has taken place. Of course, the media campaign is very important-it is getting the message into everyone's homes-but it is only part of the picture. It is interesting to note that the media and information element amounts to only 15 per cent of the total $100m committed by governments in the first three years.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter of public importance does not mention the other facets of the campaign. It does not mention the two major research projects being undertaken at the universities of Western Australia and New South Wales, to which Senator Collins referred. It does not mention the rehabilitation programs which importantly have taken place, as Senator Baume mentioned, in prisons, and in the wider community for the adults, the young people and even the children. It does not mention the special programs that are being instituted and targeted to specific groups in the community such as young people, women, children and Aborigines.

I place particular importance on the work done in education and training for professionals who work with abusers and potential abusers. I referred before to the needs which people meet by drug use and abuse. It is very important that, parallel with attacking the problem of drug abuse, we show people how to meet their needs in other ways: the need for better relationships with others, which is why many people go to the pub; the need to relieve loneliness or depression, although it is not generally understood that alcohol is a depressant and not a stimulant; and the need to get adequate sleep or pain relief, and that relates to things such as alcohol but also prescription drugs. This work is being done increasingly in schools, community centres, health centres and other places which are not directly related to the drug campaign. Those running the programs need training and information to carry out this task, and this they are getting through those joint Federal, State and Territory initiatives.

It is also very important that parents, teachers and community leaders understand that they act as role and behaviour models for young people. The children of alcohol abusers do not have a greater risk of alcoholism itself through heredity but rather because they see their parents dealing with problems by escaping into alcoholic oblivion and they learn to do likewise. Similarly, when I was working in schools I found that many young people, particularly girls, asked for minor pain-killers-not because they had pain but because that is what their mothers did when they had a problem. So they would ask for a few disprin because they were not coping very well with school, perhaps, or with their friends.

Finally, I deal with some of the demonstrated achievements of this campaign. We have talked about the aims and what is happening, but there are some demonstrated achievements in concrete terms. For example, 288 new and expanded drug abuse prevention and treatment programs have been developed on a cost sharing basis with the States and Territories. Some information drawn from the 1986-87 evaluation of those projects, and importantly that evaluation is built into the program, includes the fact that more than 1,800 schools, 825 community groups and 233 government offices receive drug educational programs and materials.

Another fact is that 562 training courses have been run for teachers and persons who come in contact with drug and alcohol related problems-which is a question I referred to previously-involving a total of more than 18,000 personnel. On top of that many teachers, for example, receive training by way of preparation for teaching itself, particularly if they are to take part in teaching courses such as health and human relations education or personal development.

Another fact is that 94 residential treatment centres received support, and 51 per cent of their clients were admitted for the first time. That seems to indicate that we are perhaps getting at the problem of cyclical treatment-clients going back into the community and returning for treatment again-which we used to see in past years, to my knowledge, with alcoholics and, I imagine, with other sorts of drug addicts, as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they work?

—The fact that they are coming back seems to indicate that they work, although some may not return for other reasons, of course. A total of 178,000 contacts involving nearly 83,000 individuals were made with non-residential treatment agencies. Some of these, and I am thinking particularly of the Odyssey House scheme in Victoria with which I have been involved in the past, do lead to intensive residential treatment. So I think that the Government has--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance brought forward in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to structure or administer the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse so as to permit the successful achievement of its goals which are shared by all Australians.

This matter has been brought before the Senate today by Senator Vanstone to emphasise the fact that the Opposition has again offered a bipartisan approach to tackling the drug abuse problem in this country. Regrettably, that bipartisan approach has not been taken up. The contribution of my colleague Senator Peter Baume in attempting to identify the difficult questions of who the targets in this war against drug abuse are and who our allies are is the type of bipartisan approach that this Government should welcome because it would better contribute to the goal that we all share of countering this abuse for the benefit of all Australians.

The Government's attitudes and the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made it very clear that it was of a political nature and that he could see a political advantage in this issue very early in the piece. As honourable senators will recall, he said that as a goal of his second term in government he would initiate a national campaign against drug abuse. As we all know, the problem of drug abuse exists in Australia as it does everywhere in the world. In this country it is primarily a problem of the abuse of alcohol and tobacco, which is a point that has been reiterated by a number of speakers in today's debate. In other words, it is primarily a problem of the abuse of legal drugs. I also remind the Senate, as have other senators, that, if we look as death statistics alone, 97 per cent of drug related deaths in Australia are attributed to the taking of not illegal but legal drugs. This problem ranges from adolescence right through all ages of life. It is not just a problem of the young, as some say, although in the case of the young there might be more opportunity for us to change habits.

When the Prime Minister addressed the drug summit he talked about fighting drug abuse and referred to the `devastation which is wrought by the illicit drug trade'. He, like most of Australia, had in mind the high profile and tragic circumstances of what is nevertheless the secondary or ancillary problem and not the primary problem of the abuse of legal drugs. That is the first mistake that he made, because it established a wrong emphasis in the whole campaign. The Prime Minister asked the summit why there should be a focus on illegal drugs and then said:
Because governments obviously have a particular responsibility as regards illegal drugs. Our campaign will necessarily focus especially on them.

It may well be correct that governments have a responsibility in relation to illegal drugs, but we on this side of the chamber say that governments equally have a responsibility in relation to the losses and suffering that occur in the community from the abuse of the primary problem, that is, the abuse of legal drugs. Of course, it is much easier for the Government to be seen to be doing something in relation to illegal drugs. If governments give enforcement authorities more resources or new powers, it is easy for governments to point to something. Of course, that was the emphasis at the summit because the summit was a political meeting. As the Prime Minister also said:

The presence here today of the Premiers of all States, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and many Commonwealth and State Ministers is testimony to the importance of the task that is before us.

In other words, everyone wanted to be seen to be doing something, and not to be part of the national summit was to risk being labelled as unconcerned, unaware or, in the worst instance, uncaring. Of course, lots of Commonwealth money would be spent, some of it on worthwhile services, and it was not surprising that all States wanted a share of that cake. But why a national summit, with a communique that was no doubt written before the summit commenced? It was certainly not to illustrate that a problem existed, because everyone knew of the existence of it. It was in order for the Government to be seen to be doing something. That is the wrong emphasis. As one commentator unkindly said, it was an emphasis directed at the ballot box nerve.

This perception was, of course, reinforced with the distribution of 5.4 million glossy brochures, at enormous cost to the taxpayer, again to tell the public what it already knew, that is, that there was a problem and that all our kids were at risk. We all know that this problem is with us, and we did not need the Government, through the medium of glossy brochures, to tell us so. But the Government wanted to set the perception, in a very public way, that it was doing something. However, even accepting, which I do not, the priorities that were set by the Government in the campaign, the breakdown of State and Federal spending shows distortions. An article by one academic, Ross Ramsay, in the Legal Services Bulletin indicates that he at least shares my cynicism. He divided anticipated spending at this time into the following categories: law enforcement, extra funding, $58m; public relations/media/advertising, $44m; treatment and rehabilitation, $6m; and drug research, $0.6m. Looking at the lack of emphasis on the low profile treatment and rehabilitation, he said:
Because of these inconsistencies we should not be too quick to believe the rhetoric and accept the drug offensive as a humanitarian act of caring government.

We all know the public outcry that followed, and in fact the percentage of funds to be spent on treatment and rehabilitation was then increased. I do not mean that more money need not be spent on policing-it still does. It is estimated that only 5 to 10 per cent of all heroin that enters the country is intercepted. Police forces in this country are still under-resourced. Despite the existence now of the National Crime Authority and despite new coercive powers, no-one is suggesting that the Mr Bigs of organised crime in this country are being convicted. The enormous sums of money involved in the international drug trade enable the potential for corruption as in no other area of organised crime. There is no suggestion that what has been contributed so far has resulted in a significant slowdown in the movement of heroin.

We all know the shortcomings of the Coast- watch service, which again is under-resourced and subject to major political embarrassment recently. We all accept the importance of education in pointing out the dangers of taking hard drugs. However, I suggest that those primarily who have reached that stage are beyond flashy brochures and healthy living. The young, most particularly, have underlying problems, such as boredom from unemployment, low self-esteem, poor relationships, a sense of worthlessness and a feeling that nobody cares. For those who have reached that stage, I suggest that the real goal is to identify them and to provide programs of rehabilitation for them and, most importantly and what is often neglected, ongoing support. Voluntary organisations, both church and community, do a marvellous job in this area and deserve greater support, and had the Government perhaps provided greater support to them rather than spending the money on glossy brochures we would all be better off.

Certainly, prevention is better than cure and, just as important, a role therefore for the Government is to identify and support those people most likely to become at risk. There will always be exceptions, but with caring parents, caring schools and a caring community recognising the inherent importance of each and every individual and on the lookout for problems and willing to proffer support, with proper professional support made available when needed, we can minimise the danger. However, I readily concede that the scenarios of broken homes, unemployed parents and financial stress do not make the ideal easy to achieve. That is why we on this side of the chamber stress support for the family, both marital support through marriage guidance councils and other means and financial support. We also support voluntary organisations and community support mechanisms.

I speak in general terms because, although now well down the track, still inadequate research is being done into the cause of abuse and addiction. That is a matter of regret following the Government's campaign. All of this tends to camouflage the greater problem, a problem that has been particularly emphasised by my colleague Senator Peter Baume today, namely, the enormous cost to our society in economical and social terms that flows from an abuse of legal drugs. As every parent knows, the challenge of education of children in the sensible use of alcohol is a great challenge indeed, with so many role models appearing to provide a counter influence. I regret to say that too many parents do not appreciate the importance of the model that they personally offer.

Governments can influence behaviour, and in this area governments should be prepared to do so, through means of taxation, subsidies-as was mentioned by Senator Coulter today-prohibitions on certain advertising and types of advertising when the industries involved are not prepared to set sufficiently high standards for themselves, restrictions on smoking when it affects others and random breath tests, which none of us like in some ways but which clearly are contributing to a lower road death toll due to alcohol abuse. They are just some examples of where government can play a role. Those who say that there is not a role for government in this field are wrong.

Governments can educate, and I would suggest that they have made insufficient effort to educate people in this country, particularly young children. I commend for the Government's attention the American program of `Say ``No'' to drugs and alcohol', which was initiated particularly to influence the behaviour of young children in American schools recently. If young children can grow up to believe that those who smoke or drink too much are stupid, that those habits show immaturity and a lack of sophistication and failure, rather than what they learn so often in our community, that they represent maturity, sophistication and success, we might be heading in the right direction,

But kids have to be given an alternative. Education in itself is insufficient. Their strengths need to be rewarded. They need to be otherwise stimulated and provided with challenging activities. That gets back to the responsibility of all of us to care and to make the effort. So much of the subject of this debate is a human problem. This Government, which saw it simply in terms of interdiction, enforcement, education and rehabilitation, missed the point. It is just not that simple. If the Government were serious about the problem it would not have seen the answer in summitry; it would not have seen the answer in political gain for itself; it would have seen the answer in what we have suggested. It would have tried to find a bipartisan approach to dealing with one of the major problems that face our community so that we could get on and together achieve worthwhile goals, which are not presently being achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards the end of Senator Hill's contribution I was beginning to think that he was being quite constructive but he spoilt it again right at the end. This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance proposed by Senator Vanstone, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to structure or administer the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse so as to permit the successful achievement of its goals which are shared by all Australians.

I think the point has already been made this afternoon but I want to make it again: the Government-presumably the Federal Government is what is being referred to-does not structure or administer the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse. The national campaign is a joint initiative by all Australian governments-Federal, State and Territory-to combat drug abuse. I sincerely hope that what I thought Senator Hill was saying when he suggested that when the governments of Australia came together at the summit meeting in April 1985 they agreed to take part in this campaign because of pressure they felt was being brought to bear upon them is not the case. In fact, this is a multipartisan campaign. I suggest that if the Opposition coalition feels itself left out in the cold it must surely be as a result of its own choice. Up until now it has done absolutely nothing but criticise in the most carping fashion, making what political points it could, grasping hold of straws and beating them up into quite spurious allegations in many cases.

How could we possibly forget that only eight days ago at the Liberal Party conference the leader of the Party, Mr Howard, made a speech pleading for a bipartisan approach? That is fine-much better late than never. But since then we have had no real indication of the sincerity of that plea. The campaign manager, Dr John Loy, wrote to Senator Vanstone on 12 April, only six days ago, offering to give her a detailed briefing. From the contribution of Senator Vanstone today, one would have thought that her request for information had been totally rejected. That is simply not the case. She has been offered the information that is available at a time when it is widely available. An enormous amount of survey work has been carried out leading up to the campaign on alcohol, probably the best researched such campaign in the world. The massive amount of research that has been done in this respect is to be released within a few weeks to give the campaign a boost. That data will then be available to all of us, including Senator Vanstone, I am happy to report.

How much research is enough? As has been said already this afternoon, we could go on researching forever and probably keep coming up with contradictory responses. But surely at some time the nettle has to be grasped, the bullet has to be bitten, and all the other cliches we can think of. We have to go ahead and use what we have available to us in the way of carefully assembled data, analysed as carefully as possible, and make inroads, if at all possible, into the very great challenge that is facing this community and which this Government has been prepared to accept. We would be much more impressed with the call for a bipartisan approach if the matter of public importance being debated this afternoon had not been posited on such completely misleading allegations and statements.

The allegation that we are using sexist stereotypes in the advertising was raised by then Senator Ryan early in this campaign, having been given the opportunity to view the advertisements. As a result of this, a series of advertisements have been used back to back-accurate representations of how boys view girls and vice versa. This has all been thoroughly tested for efficacy and acceptability. We all know that an effective advertising campaign contains clear, simple, direct and uncomplicated messages. I will come to the money that has gone into media in a moment but it would be nice if, as a result of the funding for this campaign, we were able to get across a few other messages such as the undesirability of domestic violence and the desirability of eradicating sexist stereotypes that it would be totally impracticable. It would be nicer still if the same amount of dollars were available for such campaigns. That is another question for the Government. On the question of testing of the advertisements, I assure honourable senators as an example of how the testing was done that parents were consulted before the cubbyhouse advertisement was approved. This was seen by parents generally to be a very positive, constructive and useful approach.

I have a few more comments to make about the nature of the campaign. Senator Peter Baume, in his typically constructive approach to this question, suggested that any advertising campaign or any attempt to educate the community on these issues should link us-who consider ourselves fairly ordinary and unaddicted members of the community-with those whose problems are clearly a great deal more severe. I think that notion comes through very clearly in the current series of advertisements. They show ordinary people, and try to get the message to them, what may happen to them or their children as a result of the behaviour that they currently consider to be normal, uncomplicated and ordinary. We would be a great deal more impressed by Senator Vanstone's pleas for feminism in a campaign such as this if she were not on record as having voted against the affirmative action legislation not very long ago. I think we would be even more impressed if she had remained in the chamber until the end of this debate to hear the rebuttals of many of the allegations that she had made.

I turn to the questions of domestic violence and alcohol and how these two should be linked. We have recently released research-it is now public knowledge-in the first phase of a national campaign to raise awareness of domestic violence. This research shows conflicting beliefs from the people sampled in the survey. Seventy-eight per cent believed that alcohol was a major cause of domestic violence but 77 per cent also believed-this would have to be at least a 50 per cent doubling up with both beliefs-that alcohol was just an excuse. Nearly four out of five people say it is a cause and as many people say it is an excuse. Two-thirds of the respondents say both those things. This suggests to me that in this survey we are being told nothing about the causes of domestic violence. The abuse of alcohol and the abuse of other household members are both symptoms, as has been said before in this debate this afternoon, of responses to perhaps less obvious factors, things that we have not been asking about so far. Once again I am completely in accord with Senator Baume on this-poverty, stress, depressive conditions, loneliness and the awfulness of reality can all be factors in causing both substance abuse and domestic violence. I am quoting Senator Baume. I hope he does not mind. Who knows? There is a failure of society to deal with the really deep and personal problems of many of its members.

There has been another charge-that we have been addressing the problems of illicit drugs only. That is not so. We have addressed the problems caused by both illicit and licit drugs. The alcohol campaign would be proof if such were needed. The campaign covers alcohol, tobacco and pharmaceuticals. When the 1986 survey was carried out the common perception was that the two main problems were alcohol and hard drugs. Many of us believe that although alcohol is a serious problem, hard drugs are not necessarily so, the public perception resulting from media which like sensation and which will make a great deal out of the death of one young person from a heroin overdose and practically ignore the death of a thousand people from the use of tobacco.

We were also charged that there had been a lack of consultation in the development and philosophy of the campaign. That is also nonsense. From the very beginning, the drug summit in 1985, the campaign has been developed in close coordination with the States. Working groups and task forces have been working on what are identified by the Premiers as their main priorities. I cannot believe that the Premiers and the Ministers, who nominate the members of these working parties, are ignoring the expertise of people in their own States, the many professionals who have been working for many years with the victims of alcohol and other substances. As with many of the statements Senator Vanstone made today, she has been misinformed. She met up with somebody who had not been consulted and has not looked any further to see the many people of worth, experience and talent who have been consulted and who have made an important and valuable contribution to the campaign.

Those of us who, like Senator Zakharov and I, have been concerned for many years about issues closely involved with health education and changing the behaviour of individuals know, from very long and painful experience, that behaviour is not changed overnight. Identifying the issues and training the educators are matters that have not been effectively dealt with, either in Australia or anywhere else. Many of us believe that we are experts on these issues but very few people actually have a deep and useful, or effective, understanding of what it is to be an addict, what it is to be part of a society in which all of us are potential addicts of one sort or another. In Western Australia during the 1970s we felt that it was totally inappropriate to target individual issues. We conducted social issues programs in the schools with parents and students. We talked, not about drugs in isolation, but about the whole cohort of social problems. We talked about the use and abuse of alcohol and tobacco, about the problems that affect young people at puberty, the things they need to know about childbirth, contraception and sexually transmitted diseases. We put all these things in a series of programs, not trying to stigmatise groups but saying, `This could happen to any of us. We live in a highly complex society. All of us are going to need help at one time or another. These are the things you need to know'.

The National Campaign Against Drug Abuse is probably the most valuable way we could have gone. If it is not, it is certainly not for want of trying. The talents that are available to us throughout Australian society are being focused. Funding is adequate and is being used wisely, as far as I can see. Only 15 per cent of the $100m set aside for the three years goes on media. Fifty-five per cent is spent on treatment and rehabilitation, quite contrary to what Senator Hill would have us believe. I behoves all of us, all parties in both chambers of this Parliament and in all State parliaments, to give the program our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said about the bipartisan approach which needs to be taken to this subject. Having been a professional youth worker before I came to this place, I have to disagree with the direction of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse. In saying that, I recognise that it is not just this Government that is the problem. I dealt with substance abusers under the McMahon Government, the Whitlam Government, the Fraser Government and, more recently, the Hawke Government. I would like to pay tribute to Senator Peter Baume. He gave a speech here today that I probably would have given had I had the time. As Senator Baume pointed out, the problem of substance abuse is a problem of alienation. It is a problem of loneliness, hopelessness, dispossession and stress-the awfulness of society. Drug abuse is a coping mechanism to deal with those problems and stresses. We are doomed to fail when we gear a program around a substance or the abuse of a substance. Unfortunately, I do not believe that a Liberal-National Party government would be any better than this Government in dealing with this problem. Given the way society views substance abuse, the program as it stands is probably about as good, and possibly even better, that we might expects.

SPEECH.PARA: What is needed to reduce the scourge of substance abuse is not masses of information about how terrible it is to consume these damaging substances. Senator Collins pointed out, for example, that petrol is the preferred substance of abuse amongst certain communities in certain places. It is not the substance itself that is the problem. What we need is adequate housing, satisfying work and an education system which allows young people to explore, to educate themselves, to find out about the world-an education system that is satisfying, character building and personality building, an education system which enthuses people with a real wonder at the wonders of the world, rather than an education system which produces good little boys and girls who will be good little employees. Of course, the employers get taught at different schools.

We need a more equitable distribution of the country's resources. I have worked with the Aboriginal community in the inner city of Sydney. I have worked with young prostitutes, male and female, in King's Cross, a place Senator Baume mentioned. I have dealt with young people right across the board, young people from so-called good homes in the northern beaches, from fairly wealthy families, who were thrown out of home because they could not find a job and who ended up in poverty just down the road, sleeping on the beaches.

What we need is a fairer and more just society. The National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, for a start, focuses on drugs and not on other substances. I mention briefly that the effect of the interaction of drugs on elderly people is ignored. If a person gets drugs from the veterinary surgeon for his dog, the vet calibrates the dose according to the size and weight of the dog. When manufacturers produce drugs, they have to calibrate them for children so that at such and such an age, a child receives such and such a dose. This is not the case for the elderly.

The problem is that we need a fairer and more just society in which people have equal access to resources; we do not need a campaign against substance abuse. (Extension of time granted) The reason why certain communities abuse petrol is not that petrol is the substance of choice, but that petrol is the only substance that is easily available and easily affordable. It produces the same effect as other substances, but in a more damaging way-it insulates the substance abusers from the pain of the hopelessness and despair about them. These people need effective land rights legislation which grants cultural autonomy to the Aboriginal people. That would get rid of petrol sniffing in Aboriginal communities. It cannot be done by a program designed to teach people how dangerous petrol is. What does one offer them as alternative to petrol? The pain of reality-and the reality is painful.

Petrol abuse is a way of dealing with that pain. The same applies to the alienation of the young person who has not been able to find a job for three years. We see hopelessness and despair. All the counselling in the world will not overcome the fact that that young person does not have a job, does not have economic independence and does not have a society and a community which cares for him or her. The myth of the dole bludger is still strong. Those people who are unemployed continue to feel the scourge of being called dole bludgers.

I remember when youth unemployment was about 20 per cent. At the time I was working in the community youth support scheme. People such as Doug Anthony castigated young people for being dole bludgers when a quarter of the young people could not find jobs; there were no jobs. Even today, when there are not jobs, one has to jump through hoops and be accused of being a dole bludger just to get the meagre pittance of the dole. These people need some sense of identity, a feeling of worth in the community, and some sense that the community cares.

Senator Hill, who was not being terribly bipartisan, talked about caring parents, caring schools and caring communities. We need communities with resources to have some sort of decent cultural life, we need an education system which is caring, and we need economic justice so that parents, free from poverty and homelessness, with the proper resources, can care for their children. We need a caring society, not programs against drug abuse.
