DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eighty-third report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report relates to the Committee's scrutiny work during the period July 1986 to July 1987. It describes the way in which the Committee interpreted its scrutiny principles during that period and it sets out various illustrative examples of the way in which the Committee endeavours to protect personal rights and liberties. It is very much the hope of the Committee that this report will be regarded by parliamentarians, Ministers and, most important of all, by Public Service officers as a kind of manual on how to draft certain types of regulations without infringing the Committee's principles. I would strongly urge Ministers in this Senate, and in the other place, to insist that their senior advisers on delegated legislation read this report and keep a copy of it to hand when preparing legislation for their Minister's approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will read it myself.

—I am encouraged by the Minister's comment. Ministers whose officials do not heed the guidelines set out both in this document and also in the Committee's other major report, the eightieth report in 1986, may well find themselves embroiled in lengthy, complex and time-consuming correspondence from this Committee on technical aspect of their legislation which could very easily have been avoided by a familiarity with the Committee's standards. As honourable senators know, the Committee is in fact a bipartisan committee engaged in the scrutiny of technical and legal aspects of subordinate laws made by Ministers and officials. That scrutiny is designed to ensure that such laws do not unduly affect the rights of individuals or undermine the primary law-making role of Parliament. To sum it up, quite often on this Committee we find that the large print giveth, but the small print taketh away.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has been in existence applying the same four basic principles for the past 56 years since its establishment in 1932. The interpretation and application of those principles by successive committees is subject to evolution and change. However, these adjustments are of such a gradual and predictable nature that there are very few complaints catalogued in this eighty-third report that could not have been anticipated and avoided by conscientious and diligent officials acquainted with the Committee's reports and committed to the protection of personal rights and liberties.

Chairing this Committee has been an extremely valuable learning experience for me. I think that the time has come for a little bit of blunt speaking. Some Ministers, who are personally answerable in this Parliament for laws made in their name and under this authority, are not being well served in my view by some of their officials, who do not take the Committee seriously enough. I believe that there are some officials in some departments who, because we scrupulously endeavour to avoid disallowance action, do not take the Committee seriously. As a result of this the Committee finds itself time and time again in repetitive correspondence with Ministers about legislation which fails, and obviously fails, to meet the Committee's standards for the protection of the rights of ordinary people.

Time and time again we have to write to Ministers to ask for explanatory statements which actually explain the reasons for making legislation and the impact it might have on people and businesses. Time and time again we have to ask Ministers to explain why they have resorted to the use of lengthy retrospectivity in making administrative arrangements. Time and time again we have to ask Ministers to ensure that inspectors with the necessary powers to walk onto other people's property and examine their private or business documents display proper, official, photographic identity cards and act reasonably in accordance with that express requirement appearing in the law giving them their powers.

We heard just recently in a major debate in the Senate on the protection of the environment just how widespread these powers could be. To my astonishment I heard from the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that the semen inspectors of the Queensland Government could knock at a person's door at two o'clock in the morning and demand that person produce his semen at a moment's notice and that that person would be legally bound to oblige them. I can assure the Senate that they would not get mine without a fight. This is a very serious point. It simply illustrates what we on the Regulations and Ordinances Committee know and what a lot of other people do not seem to be aware of; that the powers that are provided by regulations can be very wide ranging indeed.

We constantly ask that officials who have these awesome powers to examine people's private and business documents have official, proper photographic identity cards and act reasonably in accordance with that express requirement appearing in the law giving them their powers. Time and time again we have to ask that the exercise of administrative discretion that could seriously affect reputations, businesses or livelihoods be made subject to the justice of merits review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Time and again we have to ask that subdelegated law-making be made subject to the same parliamentary controls as is the delegated legislation that authorises it. I think that it is not an unreasonable demand. Finally, time and again we have to ask Ministers whether undertakings they have given the Committee to make amendments to protect rights are likely to be implemented expeditiously in the near and not the distant future.

This is a random sample of certain issues which continually arise in delegated legislation. Not one of these issues is a minor issue. There are, in fact, even more numerous minor issues which I do not want to bore the Senate with tonight. These are all important issues, such as questions of retrospectivity, the reason for government law-making outside parliament, the intrusive powers of government inspectors that I have just referred to, rights of appeal, parliamentary control of government law-making, and delays in carrying out promises by a government Minister. Each of these is a major issue of principle going to the very heart of the kind of free and open parliamentary democracy Australia rightly prides itself on in a world of government tyranny, official oppression and bureaucratic manipulation.

The cumulative effect of consistent deviations from the Committee's principles of justice and standards of propriety is a slow but sure decline in the quality and extent of individual freedoms in Australia. The reason for this is clear. A law-maker who is neglectful of, or merely unconscious of, the primacy of personal rights can too easily become a law-maker who is cynical about those same rights. Cynicism and contempt are two closely related attitudes, and the end of a process which perhaps started unconsciously and innocently enough is contempt for people's rights and Parliament's law. In Australia, thankfully, we are a long way from that situation, but one contributing reason for that happy state of affairs has been the existence in this Parliament for the past half century of a scrutiny committee which has been, and continues to be, prepared to put itself on the line in vigorously speaking out with a bipartisan voice when delegated law-making threatens to restrict or undermine the rights and freedoms of Australia's citizens. This consistent preparedness to apply bipartisan principle and criticise technical aspects of delegated legislation without fear or favour has undoubtedly helped to establish within the Senate a climate of sensitivity to issues of personal rights and parliamentary proprieties. It has undoubtedly heightened the interest and the watchfulness of the Parliament regarding the protection of freedom and the accountability of power. Twenty-five years ago former Senator Lionel Murphy said that the Senate:

has done something by way of supervision of delegated legislation of which the people of Australia may be proud. Journals on public law have described the Senate's action as a model that might well be emulated by other countries.
I hope it will not be wrongly construed if I also say that in 1970 Senator Murphy, as Leader of the Opposition, told the Senate:

. . . the Labor Party is so much concerned about the carrying out of these principles, regardless of whether it is in opposition or in government, that at the last federal conference the Australian Labor Party actually adopted as part of the Party's federal platform the standards which have been laid down by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Regardless of whether it is in government or in opposition the Australian Labor Party has pledged itself to the maintenance of these standards. I do not think that there could be any greater assertion of the intention of the Australian Labor Party.

That comment will not be misconstrued, I am sure, because in the same breath I remind the Senate that the senator who at times almost single-handedly made the Regulations and Ordinances Committee a force to be reckoned with on matters of principle was former Liberal Senator Ian Wood. If the present Committee is having an effect it is because of the bipartisan commitment and contribution of all senators on it.

Attempts have been made to emulate the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I am pleased to say that the most recent attempt is occurring in the Western Australian Parliament, the only Australian Parliament that has not had a parliamentary delegated legislation committee, but which has now appointed one. I am also pleased to report that the members of that committee will be visiting Canberra at the end of this month for discussions with the Regulations and Ordinances Committee on the theory and practice of legislative scrutiny.

In spite of the role of the Committee it has been my experience, and I think also the experience of my predecessor, Senator Cooney, that some public servants in preparing ministerial replies to the Committee's correspondence will justify problematical aspects of delegated legislation to the point where a disallowance debate begins to look inevitable. At that stage, when Ministers who are smothered in other crucial parliamentary and political work must look in detail at the Committee's concerns, the once intractable problem always seems to disappear. The reason is obvious. Ministers personally will invariably see the problem from the same parliamentary perspective as the Committee and they will readily agree to make appropriate amendments to protect the rights of the people or involve parliament in subsequent oversight of subdelegations-but at that stage, at what expense in wasted time and effort by the Committee and the Minister?

One of my early experiences as Chairman of this Committee was to be told very emphatically by departmental officials that a certain course of action recommended by the Committee, which involved the introduction of a very small piece of legislation into the House of Representatives correcting what the department acknowledged was wrong, was impossible for at least 12 months because of the Government's very heavy legislative program. On that occasion a discussion with the Minister's staff resulted in the Bill being drafted 48 hours later. It was quite an instructive experience for me.

The Committee urges Ministers to encourage their advisers and officials to adopt as far as they can a parliamentary perspective when dealing with the Committee's concerns about the rights and freedoms of the people. We urge Ministers to re-educate their advisers to a recognition that this Committee is not a political entity, it is not a destabilising force; it is simply a parliamentary editor whose role is to blue pencil bad laws that take away rights, the existence of which will not in the least undermine ministerial or government policy. Indeed, in many cases, by requiring subordinate policy to be predicated on respect for personal rights and parliamentary proprieties, the potential for successful implementation of that policy is enhanced.

The Committee's eighty-third report is a long and detailed document. As I said at the beginning of this statement, I hope it becomes another reference book for delegated law-makers. I do not propose at this time to refer to the details of particular inquiries or complaints reported here. After considering the report, other senators may wish to do so before debate concludes. However, I would like to say that all of the case histories summarised here came before the Committee while it was under the chairmanship of Senator Cooney, with Senator Lewis as the Deputy Chairman, the other members being Senators Coates, Giles, Vanstone and Withers. Apart from the long-suffering Senator Pat Giles, the membership of the Committee changed completely last September. However, the report is a tribute to all of the former Committee members for their bipartisanship and for their independence of mind and action while on this Committee. It is a tribute to their strength of resolve in obtaining ministerial undertakings to protect rights. While any scrutiny committee cannot but be greatly assisted by legal advisers of the calibre of Professor Douglas Whalan or Professor Dennis Pearce, obviously committee members take the hard decisions and fight hard for the right outcome. Like so many of their predecessors, Senator Cooney and Senator Lewis set standards of top quality parliamentary scrutiny by a committee whose great strength is that it owes no obligations to any government while doing its special technical work. I think I speak on behalf of all of the present Committee members in expressing an intention to maintain those high standards.

Before I conclude, I would like to say that the Committee has included as Chapter 2 of this report a personal statement which Senator Cooney made to the Senate last June summarising his view of the purpose and importance of scrutiny committees. I have no doubt that that statement by Senator Cooney will become a standard text throughout the Commonwealth parliaments of the world where the task of legislative scrutiny is undertaken, and I commend it and the report itself to other senators.

Another of the learning experiences that I have had-and I am sure this is shared by all other members of the Committee-is of the expertise and diligence of the staff that serves this Committee. I conclude by paying tribute to them and, in particular, to the Committee's Secretary, Mr Peter O'Keeffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to speak on the Committee's eighty-third report. This is the first general report tabled by Senator Collins as Chairman of the Committee, and I wish to congratulate him on that. I think I speak for all of the Committee members when I also congratulate Senator Collins for the effective way in which he is chairing and leading the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in a bipartisan spirit, irrespective of the colourful examples that he gives on tabling the report. He serves, as the rest of the Committee, with a commitment to the ideal that citizens' rights should not be undermined by delegated legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest report is, in my view, one of the most important the Committee has tabled. It is a long document, the longest report in the Committee's 56-year history, but the kernel of it is in the first 50 pages, which should be read by interested senators and by all Ministers in whose names delegated laws are made by the bureaucracy, and in whose names delegated laws are sometimes not well enough made by that same bureaucracy.

I strongly endorse Senator Collins's remarks that this report and the Committee's general report for 1986-87 should be treated as if they were a form of manual for the makers of certain kinds of subordinate provisions. There is a little too much repetition in the flaws we encounter. Indeed, this point has been made before. When the Committee tabled its eightieth report, on 15 October 1986, my colleague Senator Vanstone said:

One frustrating aspect of our work arises when the Committee writes to a Minister to repeat a point which had already been made to that or another Minister on an earlier occasion. Honourable senators will see in the report a number of themes repeated over and over again. Although the Committee has adopted the practice of being as open as it can be about its work, making statements in the Senate and incorporating or tabling its correspondence, it still seems to take a very long time before particular flaws in delegated legislation are dealt with and weeded out.
Senator Vanstone also commented:

The Committee is anxious to see that flaws which it identifies are not repeated, because the exercise of drawing these flaws to the attention of Ministers in order to get them fixed is not so much a waste of the Committee's time as it is a waste of the Minister's time, because the problem could have been avoided by reference to the Committee's reports and tabled correspondence before drafting of the offensive instrument.
I endorse those remarks. It is regrettable that I feel I have to do so 18 months after they were first made.

I wish also to draw the attention of the Senate specifically to some aspects of the report which has been tabled and which I believe are of great significance to the process by which Parliament delegates law-making powers and the subsequent process by which Ministers make laws outside Parliament. Principle (a) of its terms of reference requires the Committee to study delegated legislation to ensure that it is in accordance with the enabling statute. Yet very frequently the statute itself will give little indication of how delegated powers are to be exercised. When general law-making delegations are conferred on Ministers and others by Acts I think it is incumbent on the Parliament to ensure that the limits and, more importantly, the purposes of those powers are clearly expressed. It is the tradition of the Committee in its scrutiny to ignore the policies, the merits or the purposes of delegated legislation unless these expressly or impliedly infringe the Committee's principles. In its eightieth report the Committee clearly stated:

In applying its Principles the Committee will not accept that it is the policy of the Executive to so use delegated legislation as to expressly negate those Principles. Such legislation will, by definition, infringe the Committee's Principles.

Having said that, and having thus clearly identified the proper limits of the Committee's narrow role, the Committee does not necessarily step outside that role when it criticises the Ministers or other subordinate law-makers who do not make the policies, the merits or the purposes of executive laws obvious enough for parliamentarians and the public to know what they are. That is the function of a good explanatory statement-to set out the legal authority for executive laws, to explain why more of such laws are needed, to indicate what their impact will be, to refer to any community or industry consultations on which they are based and then to describe, in language that a non-lawyer can understand, just what each of the new laws means.

In my view, the vast majority of the explanatory statements for delegated legislation are unsatisfactory, for the simple reason that they do not do this-they do not give the Parliament and the people enough information about why a law is necessary, what consultations preceded it or what impact it will have. Explanatory statements that accompany delegated legislation to this place should, in my view, be more carefully drafted than the explanatory memoranda of Bills, for the simple reason that at least a Bill will be thoroughly and publicly debated in two Houses of Parliament in the full glare of the media. Delegated legislation is not like that. Too often it is drafted behind closed doors, without consultation, without circulation of exposure drafts, in the context of enabling legislation which does not clearly spell out the purpose and limits of subordinate law-making powers. Chapter 3 of the Committee's eighty-third report calls for greater attention to be paid to these aspects of the process of making laws outside the confines of the Parliament. I strongly urge senators, Ministers and their advisers to read chapter 3 very carefully. It contains various ideas and proposals for greater openness in the process of subordinate law making. These are ideas whose time has come. Parliament and the people want more information on executive laws made by Ministers in the Federal sphere and it is the job of this Committee to take the lead in asking for that information, not to evaluate or criticise policy or purposes, but so that others may do so in the exercise of their lawful democratic or parliamentary rights.

The Committee's main task remains twofold-to protect the rights, freedoms and liberties of the citizen which can so easily and so unwittingly be erased by subordinate laws; and to ensure that such parliamentary protection can continue to be given by protecting the role of the Senate and the Parliament in the oversight and supervision of ministerial law making. On 17 December last year Senator Collins told the Senate that the Committee's function is to `press caution on those who might seek unnecessary subordinate powers for themselves by means of unnecessary subordinate laws made by themselves'. That indeed we seek to do and will continue to do with the bipartisan support of this chamber and in the interests of protecting personal rights. Also, I would also like to endorse Senator Collins's remarks concerning the high standard and quality of the work given by the secretariat to the Committee in the performance of our functions. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday afternoon when speaking on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) I pointed to this Government's hypocrisy in terms of what it says it will do and what in fact it does. A further recapitulation of my point on Friday is the promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that taxes would fall in 1987-88 as a percentage of gross domestic product. One should note the fact that the performance of this Government has meant that the total tax revenue so far in this financial year is up 14.5 per cent instead of the figure of 8.5 per cent in the Budget. The rhetoric simply does not match the performance. The Australian tax bill has jumped by more than 80 per cent from the coalition years in 1982-83. This is double the rate of inflation and after taking inflation into account represents a real rise of 25 per cent. Huge rises in income tax provided most of this tax increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Tax relief is not on the Government's agenda for Australians generally. As I said on Friday, that process has been assisted in terms of huge consumption taxes which have boomed since this Government came to office. Consumption taxes have been the fastest growing taxes in Australia with 110 per cent growth under the Hawke Labor Government-110 per cent in a mere five years. This year sales tax is up 18 per cent-half as much again as the Budget forecast of 12 per cent. Taxpayers have had to pay out to wipe off the record Hawke 1984 Budget deficit of $8 billion to bring about this year's expected surplus. That deficit should have been removed by cutting Government spending and not by increasing taxes. How hypocritical and cynical it is of this Government, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister, to say that they will have a surplus Budget this year. It is absolutely outrageous.

The capital gains tax of which I spoke on Friday also is a big factor in the climate of economic instability through which we are currently passing. I drew attention to the fact that this Government has not permitted relief for those investors who suffered in the stock market crash of October last year. We cannot expect the Government to revise its capital gains legislation in comparison with other Western economies. Whereas private business and investors in Australia are confronted with a maximum long term capital gains tax of 52.25 per cent, the rate is 30 per cent in Britain, 28 per cent in the United States, 18 per cent in socialist Sweden and Canada, 16 per cent in France and zero in Italy and West Germany. One might wonder why investment has increased by only 5 per cent over the past six years.

This Bill does nothing to create any major reform of the capital gains tax, nor does it alter such other anti-business impositions as the fringe benefits tax. Last month the Confederation of Western Australian Industry (Inc) stated that taxation was the principal concern of business in my State. This Bill fails to address the fact that the fringe benefits tax is levied on meals provided in the construction industry through recognised awards, a cost estimated last December at $1,000 annually for each worker, with perhaps $100m cost to the construction industry, and an extra $2m cost to the North West Shelf project alone. The cost of meals comprises 15 to 20 per cent of the total fringe benefits tax receipts. That has exceeded expectations by $135m to raise $855m for this Government in 1987-88-a further example of this Government's gross dishonesty. This legislation therefore perpetuates the real taxation story of the Hawke Government, which has obtained on average a real increase in taxation revenue of 4.7 per cent each year since coming to office, culminating in a record 24.8 per cent of gross domestic product in 1986-87. The average increase under the coalition Government was 3.3 per cent-3.3 per cent versus 24.8 per cent.

The underlying reason that we have a big taxing Government that requires a succession of taxation Bills is that the Australian Labor Party Government for all its talk of austerity and responsibility is a record spending Government. No other government in this country's history has had the spending capacity of this Government. Since 1983 there has been a real rate of increase in outlays of 3.8 per cent annually, compared with 2.1 per cent under the coalition. We are still paying for the splurge in the early Hawke Government Budgets so that it could go to the polls early, even though it also promised not to do that, and win votes at any cost to the taxpayer.

We should not forget that last September Senator Walsh virtually let the cat out of the bag with his reference to 200 programs that the Government lacked the courage to abolish. If the Government had had the courage to abolish those programs, the taxpayer would not have been footing the bill to try to give it a surplus this year. Underneath the technicalities of this and similar legislation lies the reality that ordinary Australians must meet this Government's bills. Last October it was estimated that the tax burden per head for 1986-87 had risen by $403, an increase of 8.5 per cent. Of this, $340 had been imposed by the Federal Government.

The Government appears to have rejected valuable evidence from overseas that the best way to obtain revenue and to stimulate economic growth is through lower rates of direct taxation, a remedy being applied in New Zealand and other economies. Cutting the top rate of income tax in the United States under the Reagan Administration resulted in three times as many Americans reporting incomes above $US1m, with revenue rising from $US5 billion to $US15 billion, and the share of tax carried by millionaires rising from 1.7 per cent to 5 per cent. Taxpayers earning more than $US100,000 increased their tax payments by 57 per cent. Reduction in top marginal rates in Britain resulted in the top 5 per cent of taxpayers increasing their contribution to the total tax burden to 27 per cent, it having been 24 per cent under the previous Labour Government. Lower marginal tax rates actually produce a greater degree of equity. We have been pushing for that for a long time. It is something that we put to the electorate at the last election, and we still believe today that it is of great benefit.

It is no accident surely that, with drastically lower tax rates, income tax in the United States of America amounts to 12 per cent of gross domestic product, whereas steep marginal rates in Greece and France, for example, yield only 4 per cent and 6 per cent of GDP. The United States, Switzerland and Turkey, which have low or drastically reduced marginal tax rates, enjoyed cumulative increases in real gross national product between 1980 and 1985 of 13 per cent, 9 per cent and 27 per cent respectively. Overtaxed economies such as Belgium, the Netherlands and Greece managed to achieve total growth of only 2 per cent, 3 per cent and 4 per cent. The figures tell the story, but will this Government learn, will it compare and will it adjust its policies? No. The Government is simply hell-bent on taxing people at higher and higher rates. Belgium, a country that markedly increased marginal tax rates, experienced a fall in real tax revenues by 9 per cent from 1981 to 1984. In contrast in the United States of America in 1984 Federal tax revenue rose by 5.4 per cent.

As we debate an essentially minor piece of taxation legislation, we should not forget that the taxation and spending policies of this Labor Government have produced a number of warning signals within the economy. Motor vehicle registrations for 1986-87 at 376,000 represented a decline of 21 per cent on the previous year and 26 per cent on 1984-85. A rise last December has to be viewed in the context of this massive two-year decline. It is a significant comment on the way that this Labor Government taxes the small business sector that 1986-87 saw a record level of 8,600 bankruptcies. The Hawke Government has an annual average of 6,570 bankruptcies compared with average figure of 4,700 for the coalition years.

Again, it is a useful indication of the effect of Labor policy that in December the Housing Loan Insurance Corporation reported that 1986-87 had been the worst year for mortgage insurance, with $26m in claims and a 28 per cent increase in loans in default. Home buyers are victims of the taxation squeeze. Their disposable income is being reduced all the time. The consumption taxes on day to day things are being put up all the time, and the money available to them to provide for themselves is greatly reduced.

We should all take note of predictions, made only two months ago, by the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research that Australia's continuing economic weaknesses in regard to trade would not allow for a truly sustained fall in interest rates. If we want to attract the domestic and overseas investment that is the only effective long term mechanism for growth and recovery, we must look as a nation at lower corporate taxes, measures of reform that this Bill does not encompass.

What this Bill will achieve, indisputably, is to add more pages to Australian taxation legislation. When it comes to adding to the rule book, this Government really knows how to do it and it is probably its greatest achievement. It would not have gone amiss for the Treasurer to have heeded the remarks last November of Mr Geoff Lehmann, of Peat Marwick Hungerfords, who noted that there were now some 200 to 300 pages of inoperative tax law which could be deleted without any effect whatsoever. As a Liberal I do not make this complaint out of a simple concern for legislative tidiness. There is a real evil in unnecessarily complex taxation law in that it allows fewer taxpayers to manage their own affairs and even to understand them. A great responsibility is thrust upon tax agents, while complexity confers yet greater effective powers on the Commissioner of Taxation and his employees.

In Western Australia in October 1987 serious allegations were raised that officers of the Australian Taxation Office were increasing assessments on professional and business taxpayers for capricious and intimidatory reasons. A television journalist had her assessment raised from $6,000 to $60,000. A Taxation Office employee actually boasted to an accountant that for the journalist to resist the assessment would be a futile exercise. The officer was actually proud of the fact that the assessment had been raised from $6,000 to $60,000. There has not been a satisfactory denial to allegations raised by a Western Australian colleague at the time of threats to witnesses in taxation cases of a deliberately unsympathetic examination of their own affairs if the information they gave was too favourable to the taxpayer being investigated. Also reported were threats of 200 per cent penalties, or an examination of 4 to 5 years of returns if a Taxation Office decision on a current return was not accepted.

I do not suggest for a moment that such capricious and intimidatory behaviour is standard practice among conscientious employees of the Taxation Office. What does lie at the heart of the problem is that the legislative process at the behest of this Government, creates so complex a legal minefield that a few bullies, who are inevitably present in any large organisation, gain scope to intimidate essentially law abiding Australians. We will remove the threat only when taxation legislation becomes simpler, and becomes simpler because we reduce the tax burden on the business community and on the individual.

This legislation, while giving effect to some minor improvements, does nothing whatsoever to alter the thrust of policy of a high spending, high taxing Labor Government. Unless this policy is changed, and there is a real lowering of the tax burden, our economic problems can only increase. As a result, the Opposition is particularly concerned about the direction of the economy and we are moving an amendment to the second reading motion which quite clearly states our concern that this Government is the highest taxing government in the postwar history of Australia; that an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue; that there will be an estimated $71 billion in tax revenue in 1987-88, which is a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection; that the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax-and sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax. I remind the Senate that this consumption tax, which applies to things such as flavoured milk, ice-creams and orange juice, hits families, whom supposedly this Government is out to help. In fact, the Government is in the throes of strangling families.

The Government is the master of the consumption tax, and it is growing faster under this Government than any of its other record breaking taxes. Without the incentive to invest in work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86 billion foreign debt. It is just something that we must continue to push the Government on, from a very difficult standpoint, to ensure that we get back to a taxation system which Australians can afford and which is equitable, and one that will not put the next generation and the generation after that into debt. I am terribly concerned at the way taxation in this country is going, and until such time as we have a reversal and a more equitable situation pertains we can only go even further into the taxation minefield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987, which makes several changes to the income tax law. They include a withholding tax exemption to encourage offshore banking and rollover relief for reorganisation of trust units involving the insertion of a company between the unit trust and the unit holders. Certain changes are made to the taxation of superannuation payments and the Bill also provides for the abolition of special write-off provisions for buildings used to house research activities, and there are a number of other minor amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not oppose the second reading of the Bill but we have chosen to move an amendment at the second reading stage in the following terms:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Senate notes that:
This Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
An estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
There will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, A $5.5 billion increase in the previous year's collection;
The Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and

Without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $83 billion foreign debt strait-jacket without further reductions in our standard of living'.

One feature of this Government's stewardship which stands starkly before all Australians is its avaricious appetite for more and more taxes. Not only has this Government the singular distinction of being the highest taxing government since Federation in respect of personal income tax and many other taxes, but it has also pursued its greed with the introduction of a vast array of indirect taxes. The Government had the absolute audacity to involve itself in the debate which prevailed in the Liberal Party and the National Party for some time as to the relevance of an indirect tax vis-a-vis personal income tax, saying at the same time that it had no intention of introducing a consumption tax. However, the Government's indirect taxes have been increasing at a rate of 15 per cent annually, and the base has been broadened very significantly. The ingenuity and deviousness that this Government has applied in continuing new and different taxes has shown a dedication to rip off the Australian workers and taxpayers matched only by the dishonesty that it has pursued in masking their application. Rather than announcing in the August Budget of each year the hefty hikes in indirect taxes on commodities such as beer, petrol and cigarettes, the Hawke Government has chosen in an obsequious and rather hidden way to automatically index increases on a regular basis without announcing the level that the increases have reached.

For the Government to claim that it will not introduce a consumption tax when it has done more than any other government to widen and increase indirect taxes is, frankly, blatantly dishonest. It is another untruth that sits on the mantelpiece with Mr Hawke's promise that he would not introduce a capital gains tax and his more recent promise to all Australians that there would be no child in Australia living in poverty by the year 1990.

Let me refer for a moment to the matter of this Government's contribution to the amount of personal income tax that ordinary Australians pay. Such has been the effect of bracket creep that a person on average weekly earnings is now inside the third income bracket and is paying tax at the second highest marginal tax rate. Using the statistics for the 1984-85 taxation year, 65 per cent of male and female taxpayers were earning incomes of less than $19,000 a year, which implies that 35 per cent were paying more. These figures are two years old, so it is reasonable to assume that now decidedly more than 35 per cent of Australian taxpayers are earning more than that amount. We can assume that well over one-third of the population is paying 40c in the dollar taxation at the margin.

In September 1985 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) commented that in the early 1970s the top rate of income tax applied to people on five times average weekly earnings, while at the same time he went on to say that in 1985 the top rate of taxation cut in at 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings. Of course, three years later we know that it is cutting in at less than 1 1/2 times average weekly earnings, even after the so-called great taxation reforms.

If we convert the income figures at which the top rate of income tax applied in the early 1970s to current dollars we find that to be on the same footing the top rate would have to cut in at $126,000, but, of course, in actual fact it cuts in at $35,000. The Commonwealth's claim on an ever-increasing proportion of people's incomes through the action of inflation continues unabated, and there are certainly no signs from this Government that it intends to do anything about it. While the Government sits by and refuses to address this issue it has to be judged to be as guilty of the same immorality and cheating that is levelled at some of the Australian taxpayers.

If wages rise over the next three years at the same rate that they have risen over the past four years, a further 2.25 million people will cross over into higher taxation brackets. In fact, in 1987-88 alone, three-quarters of a million people will move into higher tax brackets; three-quarters of a million people will be paying more taxes than they were last year. Of course, the impact of this process on families is quite dramatic. Families on an average weekly income with two children paid 13.2 per cent of their income in tax in 1983, while by 1990, on the Government's present form, they will be paying 20.8 per cent of their income in tax. That equates to an increase of more than $70 a week in income tax. This Government is asking people of very ordinary means, with modest incomes by any standard, to pay exorbitant amounts of tax on their ordinary incomes and then to pay absolutely punitive rates at the margin if they are prepared to go out and do some overtime to keep their heads above water.

The persistent refusal by the Labor Government to adjust the taxation brackets upwards to compensate for inflation now leaves the Government in the ridiculous position that it is actually taxing people on social security benefits. A person over 21 years of age with no dependants receives unemployment benefit of $104.75 per week or an amount of $5,447 per year. This means that he is inside the first tax threshold by $348. We are now at the ludicrous stage where this Government is giving taxpayers' money in the form of social security benefits to people it judges to be in very real need and then taking the same money back in the form of taxes. One wonders just how absurd this Government will allow the situation to become.

For this Government to claim that it has performed an economic miracle is, by the measure of even this Government, audacious and outrageous. It is obviously an apparition able to be seen only by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. The truth of the matter is that Australia's economy is in grave peril, as it was before the recent by-elections, and it remains in grave peril. It will take Labor more than by-election disasters to generate an economic miracle. If this Government imagines that it can convert the view of the public of its economic performance simply by pronouncements that the worst is over, that the miracle is performed, that there is light ahead at the end of the tunnel, it will continue to fail. The Government, in its panic, has chosen to discard honesty and integrity as part of its luggage down the road.

The one area where there is some immunity from bracket creep is company tax. But what this Government has done to overcome the problem of not attracting the benefit of additional revenue through inflation is simply to legislate to increase company tax from 46c to 49c in the dollar. This is at a time when competing nations are reducing the levels of corporate taxation. In Great Britain the corporate rate of taxation has been progressively reduced to stand at 35 per cent. In the United States it has been reduced to 34 per cent. In Singapore it has been cut from 40 per cent to 33 per cent. In Hong Kong it has been reduced from 18.5 per cent to 18 per cent. Canada, Germany, France and Japan are examining ways of reducing corporate taxation even further. Australia stands out in the crowd because this is the only country in which corporate tax rates have been significantly increased-from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. Of course, the Australian system is worsened by this Government's foreign tax credits system, which demands payment of Australian tax on repatriated earnings equivalent to the difference between the tax paid on them overseas and the 49 per cent normally imposed in Australia.

Yet we are told that there is an economic miracle. The miracle is that any of these companies are able to pay any tax at all. The miracle is that they are able to employ people. One only need ask any of the 600,000 people who are unable to find jobs about the level of the miracle. This Government, with its obsession with extracting more and more tax from ordinary Australians, has with all its additions and amendments to the tax Act made it simply impossible for taxpayers even to begin to read and understand the Act. It has become impossible for ordinary Australians to read the laws and to determine their taxation liability.

To begin with, even the numbering of the Act is impossible. In the Income Tax Assessment Act we have a section 124zaga (1) (a) (ii) and a section 124zah (1a) (c). The relatively simple process of renumbering the Act would greatly assist taxpayers and help to make the system fairer and more workable. The continual patch-up of the Act and the complexity of new sections deprive ordinary taxpayers of even being able to read the law. Let us consider this classic from the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act: an employer examining whether a food allowance he pays employees travelling away from home is a fringe benefit finds the following in the definition section. `Living away from home food fringe benefit' he is told, is an `expense payment fringe benefit'. This term is itself defined, so he looks at that definition to find that an `expense payment fringe benefit' means a fringe benefit which is an `expense payment benefit'. `Expense payment benefit' is itself another defined term, so he looks to find that an expense payment benefit is a benefit referred to in section 20. Section 20 contains two further internal definitions but basically says that if an employer pays for something on behalf of an employee the employer is taken to have provided a benefit to that employee. If the taxpayer can still remember what it was he was looking for in the first place, he will be pleased to learn that he has discovered the meaning of the first internal definition in the first line of a definition which runs for six paragraphs.

Most taxpayers are forced to seek advice from accountants and in many cases they themselves require to consult the Tax Office. Very often there is no relief to be found there either. A recent survey published in the Australian Financial Review indicated that 30 per cent of people inquiring at the Australian Taxation Office received answers which were either partially or totally wrong. The survey found that 44 per cent of calls were abandoned because the Tax Office was too slow in answering the query. That is not a criticism of the Taxation Office or any of its officers; it is simply a criticism of this Government for continuing to mount upon the legislation more and more amendments whose intention and meaning are obscure. The Office is very understaffed in terms of providing the services and facilities which ordinary Australian taxpayers can properly claim to be entitled to.

Not only is the taxation Act now quite impossible to read but also it is being amended in ways which have removed any semblance of equity or fairness. I give two simple examples of how the Act is designed to disadvantage the taxpayer under all circumstances. I refer to section 17. I raise this against the background of recent legislation introduced by the Government to ensure that tax is paid on the earnings of a deferred annuity under an accruals system rather than when the earnings are paid. True to form, this Government does not apply the same principles when failure to use the accruals system would result in the payment of more tax. Section 17 requires tax to be levied on income at the time it is received. Two recent constituent cases demonstrate the unfairness that results. One constituent was underpaid social security benefits for several years. When the error was detected and the appropriate payments were made taxation was imposed on the lump sum and a back payment was required. The lady concerned would not have paid any tax on the pension if it had been correctly paid to her at the time she was entitled to receive it.
