TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was drawing a distinction between the recently introduced legislation which ensures that tax is paid on the earnings of a deferred annuity under an accruals system rather than when they were paid and a situation whereby taxpayers are provided with a payment they were entitled to over a number of years in a complete financial year. I referred to a lady who had been denied pension payments to which she was eligible for a number of years. She was paid in a lump sum for one year. She was required by the law to be assessed and to pay tax. Fortunately, I was able to invoke the extraordinary procedure for waiver of a tax debt and she was not required to pay the tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The same situation applied with respect to a gentleman who came to my office with a problem in regard to workers compensation payments. He was receiving workers compensation in one financial year for a period which stretched across a number of years and was required to pay tax on that lump sum, notwithstanding the fact that it related to income earned over several years. Regrettably, in this case, like so many others, he paid tax at the higher rate rather than the ordinary rate at which he might have expected to attract tax had he received the benefit and entitlement to which he was due over the period. I understand that the Ombudsman has recommended that this unfair result be changed and the Commissioner of Taxation has undertaken to recommend to the Government that the section be changed. The Treasurer has commissioned an inquiry.

In the brief moments remaining to me I will touch upon the question of inflation as it impinges on company tax. As I said earlier, companies have not suffered from inflation-induced bracket creep, but inflation has impacted by rendering historic cost accounting virtually useless. As the Senate will well know, under current accounting practices companies are required to record their assets in their accounts at the price they paid for them-hence the term `historic costs'. A deduction is allowed for depreciation of the asset. So, in theory, by the time the asset has come to the end of its useful life the company will have been able to put away sufficient funds through deductability to ensure that it can purchase new capital or to ensure that the capital it has remains intact. Anything the firm has earned after the payment for expenses and depreciation of equipment is quite properly judged to be profit and taxed accordingly.

Of course, inflation makes an absolute nonsense of this. For example, a person who buys $1m worth of plant which has an expected life of 10 years is entitled to put away $100,000 a year by way of depreciation so that at the end of the 10-year period he has written the plant off but has provided himself with accruing cash assets to replace the plant. If he makes a profit of another $1m over the 10-year period it is a taxable profit. Under normal circumstances he would be required to pay $490,000 tax, which would leave him $510,000 to assist in the purchase of new equipment. Given that we have the problem of inflation and the present inflation rate, he would probably be required to find $1.6m to buy the same equipment. Under those circumstances, rather than making a profit of $510,000 after tax, the business proprietor would make a $90,000 loss. No allowance is made for inflation under the present tax law. When depreciation is calculated, the actual profit received by the businessman is far less than that which is shown. That is the great difficulty business has at present with inflation. Perhaps one of the few redeeming features when this Government introduced the obnoxious capital gains tax was that it recognised the insidious effect of inflation and ensured that capital gains as they fell within the tax Act were discounted by the level of inflation.

At a time when the Government is telling us that an economic miracle is on the horizon, the vast majority of Australians have a financially worse status in life than they had when this Government was elected. The vast majority of businesses are more significantly disadvantaged than they have ever been. The take-home pay of individuals has been significantly reduced. There is no sign that this Government intends to amend the provisions in any way which would reduce the level of taxation. As I have said, whilst the Opposition is not opposed to the legislation, it has moved amendments which reflect the views not only of the Opposition but also of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition, in two parts. I look at the question of the overall taxation burden placed upon the Australian community, and the plans I foreshadowed in my speech in the adjournment debate last week concerning the proposed common identifying number (CIN)-that is, the determination of the Australian Taxation Office to forge ahead with its Australia Card by another name. There have been no assurances or acknowledgments by the Government that those proposals are afoot, proposals which will again allow the debate to rage.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought I might begin with a biblical quotation from the Gospel of St Luke, chapter 2, verse 1, which says:
And it came to pass in those days, that there went out a decree from Caesar Augustus, that all the world should be taxed.

The philosophy behind the Government of this day, the Hawke-Keating Government, is to tax as much as it is humanly possible to extract from the unwilling taxpayer. There has been much discussion abroad of late. The Liberal Party was prepared to debate at its Federal Council the nature and question of tax. Yet, this Government's record since it came to office has been an increase in the tax take of 80 per cent, from $40 billion to $73 billion. This has taken place without any real argument or debate on the reason we tax, the justification for the extraction of taxation and the reason for the creation of new taxes such as the fringe benefits tax (FBT) and the capital gains tax. Senator Button even admitted in this place, in a discussion on the new rules that are to apply to the automotive industries, that the FBT had had a depressing effect on the market as a whole in its initial stages. But he said that he considered that a motor car was still a good fringe benefit and, therefore, that the market ought to and should recover. There was no discussion at that time of why the tax was justified per se. The Liberal Party has put its case very firmly. It has said that the FBT would be abolished by us but that any attempts to rort the system, in the common parlance of the day-that is, to avoid justified taxation-would not be acceptable to a Liberal-National Party government.

I think it is interesting to look at the areas in which taxation has grown and in particular the breakdown of areas in which that growth has taken place. Since this Government came to power-the only comparable figure we have is in the last Fraser Government Budget-the collection of income taxes, which includes FBT and capital gains taxes, has amounted to $50 billion. That is an increase in the vicinity of $22 billion. We have seen growth in the area which is loosely called consumer taxes-I am not quite sure how that is distinguished from consumption taxes which are paid by the Australian people and which amount to about one-third of all taxes collected. Sales tax has been the fastest growing tax in our community and has gone, in a sense, unchallenged since this Government came to office.

Sales tax for this year alone is up by 18 per cent, which is half as much again as the Budget forecast of only 12 per cent. A family on average earnings is now paying an extra $37 a week in income tax. The marginal rate has jumped by one-third to 40 per cent. Let us compare that with how consumption taxes have boomed. Sales tax, as I said, has grown in a completely stealthy fashion. It is the fastest growing tax in Australia. There has been 110 per cent growth under the Hawke Government. This is almost three times the inflation rate, more than double the 50 per cent increase in wages and benefits, and almost double the 60 per cent increase in private consumption spending.

The point was very adequately made by Premier Nick Greiner, at the Liberal Party Federal Council meeting in Melbourne only the weekend before last, that this Government imposes taxes on ice-cream, orange juice and flavoured milk but it leaves such things as pornographic magazines free from sales tax. This hidden tax, comprising one-third of the tax intake, has resulted in a massive broadening of the tax base. In fact, the percentage of indirect taxes would be greater were it not for the fact that the international oil price has dropped and therefore the amount of money raised by the oil levy has not been as great as otherwise would have been the case. So the overall take remains at one-third, yet the increase in sales taxes, in particular, has been an enormous 18 per cent this year alone.

As I said, in biblical times a directive went out that the whole world should be taxed. It seems that the Government's thesis in Australia is simply that tax shall be raised at whatever cost. A figure that I have cited before is that tax collection between 1983 and this financial year has risen by 80 per cent. It has almost doubled. Does anybody feel twice as well off? Does anybody feel 80 per cent better off? They are very real questions to ask.

The second part of the question that I wanted to address tonight is how it is being planned that we should once again be subject to the threatened Australia Card but by another name. The other night in this chamber in the adjournment debate I raised the question of the proposed CIN number. I gave the background, which I will reiterate. On 18 February 1987 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) wrote to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts advising that the Cabinet had given in-principle approval for the expenditure of $693m, over a 10-year period, to pay for the redevelopment and re-equipment of computer systems for the Australian Taxation Office. In the same letter the Treasurer requested that the Public Accounts Committee consider the matter and report back to enable a request for tender to take place by June 1987. The first submission from the Australian Taxation Office was received on 27 February 1987. Further information was sought by the Committee from the Australian Taxation Office and a public hearing was held on 30 April 1987. The Committee concluded from its review work that the Australian Taxation Office did not have a fall-back position for the possible situation when an Australia Card had not been provided for by legislation.

During a further public hearing on the 23rd March 1983 we had the opportunity to question Mr Boucher, the Commissioner of Taxation. It was a fairly rigorous form of questioning. It dealt with the submission that had been put forward in writing to the Public Accounts Committee to justify nearly $700m being spent over the next 10 years. According to that submission, it was to save $519m by way of staff savings over the period. It was interesting that that written submission, which then became the basis of that hearing, in no way dealt with the projected revenue flows over that 10-year period.

I pointed out also that a submission is to be made by the Australian Taxation Office to the Cabinet for it to make a decision on how it should proceed with regard to the various proposals concerning the so-called high integrity tax number or the CIN number-the common identifying number. My concern about the CIN number being the Australia Card revisited is simply that, during questioning, at no time was there an ability to distinguish between the proposal for the CIN number with an external power and the Australia Card. The interesting thing is that the Australian Taxation Office has the power now-it had it yesterday; it had it six months ago; it had it a year ago; it had it two years ago-to introduce a common identifying number for internal use, that is, to link on a single number all taxpayers who pay income tax, fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, sales tax and any other form of tax. It has the power to do that now. When I asked why it had not already been done, the answer was less than convincing. It went along the lines that the Taxation Office had worked out its strategies and that would require more work which would perhaps not be productive.

One of the worrying aspects was that officers had given testimony at an earlier public hearing in April 1987 that a major function of the Australian Taxation Office was as a matching mechanism-that is, to match information that came to it so that it could determine whether there was income which was not being disclosed. The officers said that they had a 60 per cent success rate in that matching process. However, they also said in testimony that without the Australia Card or something like that they did not think the success rate with the new computer equipment and matching systems would exceed 60 per cent. However, they did say that the to-be-acquired computers and matching systems could enable them more specifically and in a more worthwhile sense to target the audits that ought to be done which they thought would produce more revenue. As I said, there was no attempt in the submissions to indicate in any way what those additional revenue flows would be. Interestingly enough, the Public Accounts Committee requested the Australian Taxation Office to justify in its fresh submission the $700m purchase that stood alone from the Australia Card, or any other similar number system which would require additional legislation. It chose to interpret the phrase `stood alone' as not including revenue flows.

So the concern has arisen, and I think it is a very real concern, that somehow the Australian Taxation Office thinks it can convince the Government-and it may or may not be a party willing to be convinced-that it can proceed along a path that will give it what it sees as the benefits of the Australia Card without the intense and raging debate that took place when the Australia Card was mooted.

I back up that belief with, if you will pardon the pun, seven deadly points leading to the CIN number. Firstly, the Government has asked the Tax Office to draw up a proposal which will look at the implementation of the CIN number. Secondly, the development of the preparatory work on the CIN number has already commenced. Thirdly, Government departments will be required to supply information to the Tax Office. Obviously that will include departments such as the Department of Social Security and the Department of Community Services and Health. Fourthly, computer equipment is being purchased specifically to implement the CIN number. That point is hard to substantiate in specific terms but one cannot help but come to the conclusion that the indications are that that is occurring, because the existing mainframes already have that capacity. Fifthly, there will be a need to change existing legislation, as well as introduce new legislation, to make the CIN number legal. I believe that that is contemplated. Sixthly, it will be possible to commence with the CIN number in the course of the next financial year. Seventhly, in testimony given to Estimates Committee Cover the last week, on which I have not yet touched, there was a failure to deny that the impact of the CIN number would be any different from that of the Australia Card. As I have said, the use of the CIN number needs to be brought to the attention of the Senate and the Australian people because of the intensity of the debate which raged previously. I believe it will be a debate which will rage again.

I said that there were various indications that had come to light from both the Public Accounts Committee hearings and the Estimates Committee hearings. I would like to go over some of the evidence given. In a written submission to the Public Accounts Committee entitled `Australian Tax Office submission on Re-equipment and Redevelopment Revision of Cost-Benefit analysis account Australia Card'-which in fact was a review of the cost-benefit analysis of the Australian Taxation Office's re-equipment and development program for its new computer equipment-we saw a continual line going through it, with references to how the Australia Card would have assisted and how additional benefits and taxation collections could have been maintained.

None of what I have to say in any way disagrees with the proposition that the Tax Office should be more efficient, but I want it to be efficient in the collection of fairly and squarely based taxes. The Australian community is entitled to be aware of the proposals presently being considered, and it is only through such things as the public hearings of the Public Accounts Committee and the Estimates committees that any evidence of what is planned has started to come to light. Clearly, in my view, there is a definite attempt to reintroduce the Australia Card mark 2, to be known as the CIN number. The spending of nearly $700m on upgrading computer facilities is part of that strategy and it is developing linkages between Government departments that will be necessary to enforce the usage of that number. There is a definite plan not to inform the people of Australia and have the matter again debated fairly. The Government should tell the Australian people exactly what is planned by both the Australian Taxation Office and the Government itself, and it should allow the debate to take place again.

One of the worrying aspects that have come out of the hearings I have mentioned is that there is no security. The lines between the mainframes in the Deakin centre and in Parkes are not secure. One of the Tax Office's senior officers, Mr Seymour, gave testimony that indeed those lines could be hacked into. Further testimony was given that there was no plan to put a scrambler on those lines, to use a layman's term, because that would be subject to budgetary constraints. It may be considered or it may not. When we put that in conjunction with the statement made by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in 1986, when he told the South Australian Labor Party Conference that `privacy . . . is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property', we certainly have cause for concern.

The point of this debate is to bring to the attention of the Senate and the Australian people generally the problem that we face with this Hawke-Keating Government's collection of taxation. There is quite clearly a determination to collect taxes, and to collect them faster and more extensively than they have been collected by any other government in the history of Australia. I have outlined the enormous increases in indirect taxes, that is, consumer taxes. I have pointed out the enormous increase in the collection of direct taxes. I have said that there has been an increase of some 80 per cent in the collection of tax overall since this Government came to office. Yet where is the benefit to the Australian people? Expenditure has grown by some 13 per cent but we are not seeing an increase in the standard of living of the Australian people. We have seen dramatic swings against the Labor Party in the last month and we have seen New South Wales fall and the ALP suffer by-election catastrophes: The statement has been made that the Labor Party has lost touch with the Australian people. Indeed it has. It has lost touch with the hopes and aspirations of the Australian people-what the people expect the Government to deliver; what they expect as individuals to achieve; what they expect their children, by right, to be able to achieve; what they expect from the education system; and what they expect from the right to work and to earn a place for themselves in the Australian community. That is what the hopes and aspirations of Australia are about. They are not about being told, `That is your box over there; stay in it and like it'. Australians are not like that. When it is said that the Australian Labor Party, and in particular this Labor Government, has lost touch with the grass roots of Australia, that is what it means. It has lost touch with the hopes and the aspirations of the ordinary people. In no other area is it reflected as much as in the taxation area, where initiative is stifled and reward for effort is tightened at every point. It is only by seeing a change of government, a freeing up and realisation by the people of Australia that they can aspire, hope to achieve and be rewarded for that effort, that we will again see a prosperous nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating tonight two taxation Bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill. The Opposition has moved the following amendment to the motion for the second reading.

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and
(e) sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes;

(f) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86.77 billion foreign debt straitjacket without further reductions in our standard of living''.

These Bills and the amendment that I have just read clearly give the Senate an opportunity again to debate fundamental questions relating to the equity, fairness, efficiency and simplicity of this Government's taxation package and its taxation record. It is of regret to us on this side of the chamber that the Government does not seem prepared to participate in the debate, that again tonight, apart from the Minister who in due course will wind up the debate, Government senators have not been prepared to come in and attempt to justify this Government's taxation record. We have had a very one-sided debate; nevertheless, if the Government's supporters are not prepared to stand by its record, they can only expect a one-sided debate. As the previous speaker, Senator Bishop, has indicated, votes around the country in recent times would appear to be indicating that Australia generally is disenchanted with the hypocritical version of social equity, justice and fairness that has been proffered by this Government, particularly in the taxation area.

If one looks at these Bills, which on their face appear to deal with establishing a taxation regime for offshore banking units, one soon finds that they deal with a number of other things as well. The first Bill contains a substantial number of amendments to existing taxation laws which Mr Keating calls `unintended consequences' arising from his previous tax changes, which, I would suggest, is an indictment in itself. In other words, what we have before us represents what we have seen so often during this Government's three terms; that is, pieces of taxation legislation introduced and then, within reasonably short periods, subsequent legislation seeking to amend the first Bills because of unintended consequences. That, in effect, means that the job was not done correctly in the first instance, and in taxation law particularly that makes for a most unsatisfactory regime within which business particularly has to operate, but also with which the community has to comply.

The offshore banking units part of the first Bill, clauses 20 to 24, amends the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide a tax exemption from withholding tax which would otherwise be payable on the interest received by an Australian financial institution from the recipient of a loan offshore provided certain conditions are complied with as are set out in the Act. These provisions give effect to policy statements of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) dated 1 July 1986 and 9 April 1987. We have in this instance another demonstration of what has also been commonplace taxation practice by this Government; that is, taxation laws by announcement or by Press release and amendments reaching the Parliament a considerable period later. In some instances-as in the case of this Bill-the amendments are introduced almost two years after the laws have, in effect, been put down in the form of an announcement by the Minister. We have expressed over and over again how unsatisfactory we regard that practice to be. We accept that it is not improper to make such an announcement. What is improper is that it takes so long before the legislation reaches the Parliament. Periods extending from announcements on 1 July 1986 to April 1988 are quite unforgivable and show serious flaws in this Government's taxation administration.

We therefore find that in this instance the announcements were made in an entirely different economic environment from the one which persists today. These announcements concerning a regime for offshore banking units were made in a climate of expansion in the financial services industry and deregulation in the pre-October crash environment. The legislation was designed to attract the business of offshore banking units to Australia as a necessary function in a major financial centre. What has happened now is that that environment has significantly changed, so we are not debating the legislation in the circumstances that existed when the announcement was made. I suggest that the regime that this Government seeks to set up by this legislation was flawed in any event. It certainly will not work now and it was unlikely to have worked at the time it was first announced. Why is that? The reason is quite simple: for Australia to compete in this area it has to have a corporate tax structure that is competitive with those of our regional competitors, particularly in this instance the offshore financial centres of Hong Kong and Singapore.

The corporate tax rate in Hong Kong is about 18 per cent. I have tried to look at these figures fairly, taking into account the range of taxes that corporations have to pay. The corporate tax rate in Singapore is about 33 per cent. Of course, Singapore also has a concessional tax on the profits of offshore banking business of only 10 per cent. Japan has a corporate tax rate of 33 per cent and 43 per cent on undistributed income. New Zealand by its recent announcements has established a corporate tax rate of 28 per cent. How then, is Australia to compete, with its current corporate tax rate of 49 per cent, increased by 3 per cent by this Government? I respectfully suggest that it indicates how out of touch this Government is with international business reality. To want to establish offshore banking units in Australia is desirable, but to do so one has to offer a corporate tax regime that is competitive with those of Hong Kong, Singapore, Tokyo and New Zealand. Under the current regime that is not possible.

This is a matter of great regret, I would suggest, because the Commonwealth, the State and the private sector have spent a great deal of energy, effort and resources in investigating the circumstances required to establish a financial centre in Australia that can compete with other financial centres in the region. All political parties supported what was being sought. Therefore, we had a consensus of opinion amongst political parties and the business community to create the right environment, but this Government was not prepared to offer the necessary inducement. As I indicated, in my opinion and in the opinion of the Opposition, that is a matter of great regret. The other half of the rather petty inducement that is offered in this legislation is a threat of a 300 per cent penalty tax if the exemption is abused. But this show of strength will have little effect because very few offshore banking units will result.

Let me pass to another of the changes that are included in the first of these Bills that we are debating tonight, and that concerns another acknowledgment of error by the Government. It concerns the roll-over of capital gains tax liability for certain business reorganisations. This was canvassed in a Press release more than two years ago and again expanded upon in Press releases of September 1987. I am talking about the changes that were to be made to allow certain unit trusts to reorganise by interposing a company between the business and the unit holders. They wished to do this to gain the advantages of full dividend imputation; but unfortunately the imputation legislation, as it was presented to the Parliament and passed by the Parliament, did not allow for unit trusts to do this. So again we have the situation of the Government coming to us with changes which it now says it wants to introduce to revert to a situation which perhaps it intended right from the start but which was inadequately covered. In other words, it is another example of poor planning.

I suppose that it is reasonable for taxation advisers to take some time to isolate the shortcomings in this Government's taxation packages. I remind honourable senators that the package we have before us tonight takes an explanatory memorandum of 110 pages, and that is typical of the taxation laws that this Parliament is being required by this Government to pass-legislation that is practically impossible to interpret and therefore, not surprisingly, legislation that requires a series of amending Bills to follow to try to fix up the past mistakes that the first Bill almost certainly incorporates.

This same sentiment of concern was expressed only last week, during the Harold Irving endowed lecture to the national conference of the Taxation Institute of Australia, by Mr Mat Walsh, a partner in the law firm of Mallesons Stephen Jaques. He said that the capital gains tax had brought confusion to the business world because of a lack of clarity and ambiguities in the drafting of the legislation. He said that the consequences of the legislation imposed considerable hardship on taxpayers and that the confusion arising out of the legislation was in stark contrast to a promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) after the ill-fated 1985 tax summit. As honourable senators will recall, that was a recognition that tax laws needed to be simple and capable of reasonable interpretation. If one looks at so much of the tax laws that we have passed under this Government, as I said, one sees that it certainly has failed to meet that criterion.
I refer specifically to page 39 of Mr Walsh's address, where he said:

It is obvious, too, that the Commissioner and the Government have had difficulties in foreseeing the problems in the application of the Act and this has necessitated many changes and proposed changes in the last two years.
In my view, the legislation still requires a further extensive review for the purposes of enacting further changes to overcome its lack of clarity in drafting and ambiguities . . .

Notwithstanding the continual amendments that are coming before the chamber, here we have a taxation expert saying that it is still not good enough, it is still ambiguous, it still lacks clarity and it needs further reform. Presumably, the Government will take up that invitation and we will find in due course another amending Bill. So, at a time when the Australian public is suffering the ravages of bracket creep, a decline in real disposable income, uncertainty associated with superannuation and, in particular, a drastic reduction in the living standards of parents and dependent children, this Bill is indicative of a government out of touch with reality in the tax area.

I want briefly to look at a few of these areas in which the Australian community is suffering under the Government's taxation regime-areas that are brought out specifically in the amendment that we have put in relation to this Bill and that we hope the Senate will endorse. Firstly, let me briefly look at the Government's taxation record in relation to families. One of the major problems associated with the Government's policy towards families is its failure to take account of the inequity associated with this simple comparison: a family with one income earner, a dependent spouse and two dependent children and on $500 a week-which today is a very small amount on which to bring up children-pays 31 per cent more tax than a family with two equal income earners and no dependants and bringing home $500 a week between them. That is a blatant inequity. It is time that it was addressed by this Government. We have brought it to the Senate on many occasions and we bring it again today.

I remind the Senate that a family on average weekly earnings, with a dependent spouse and two children, requires $42 a week to restore its real disposable income to the same levels as in March 1983. So, those families are now $42 a week behind where they were in 1983. That is a demonstration of this Government's taxation record in relation to families. Family allowances have fallen 36 per cent in real terms since 1983. The dependent spouse rebate for a family with children has fallen 27 per cent in real terms.

These figures are not introduced into the debate simply for academic reasons. As all of us who participate in family law debates in this chamber recognise, the financial stress that is placed upon families is accepted by most experts as the overwhelming reason for break-ups of marriages. Therefore we on this side of the chamber say that in a debate on taxation, where we are looking at the fairness, equity or inequity of this Government's taxation policies, the Government should recognise the extra stress that it is applying to families, the cost in family tension and hardship and in many cases, regrettably, subsequent break-up, and then, if we want to take it one step further, the cost to the community in trying to do something about it. We say that this Government ought to be putting together a taxation record and policy that offers incentive for the family as a cohesive unit to remain together.

Let me touch briefly on the subject of superannuation. The Government, as we are all aware, is currently considering levying a tax on funds under management in superannuation schemes. We say that, rather than going out and searching for further additional taxes to apply in this area, the Government should be looking at the place of superannuation in the context of an examination of the total retirement welfare benefits and incomes generally within our community. In other words, rather than providing something that will have the effect of dissuading members of the community from participating in superannuation funds and planning for their own security and well-being in retirement, this Government is now talking about implementing further taxes that will dissuade them from doing so.

Surely at this time that would be a most unproductive way for the Government to operate. Surely this Government ought to be looking at the difficulties in superannuation, looking at its shortcomings in the areas of portability, preservation and vesting, and looking for ways in which we can encourage more of the community to get into superannuation funds, to invest, to provide that pool of funds that as a whole can be invested and therefore provide that security during their retirement and in turn provide less pressure upon the public purse. That is the direction the Opposition would argue that this Government should be taking at the moment. We regret that the Government in its public discussions is going in the opposite direction.

I touch on one specific aspect of the superannuation changes in this Bill which also causes me concern. I refer to the change that relates to taxation which introduces in effect, a death tax. If this Government wants to introduce a death tax that may well be so, but why not come out and say so? I am talking of the situation in which superannuation funds are not permitted to be rolled over, but rather on the death of the superannuant have to be taxed in full. This is an area on which we have heard very little from this Government. It introduces a significant change in our superannuation laws of which the public of Australia should beware because people should take these matters into account in their taxation planning. On the face of it, I respectfully suggest that this amounts to a death tax. If it dissuades people from entering into superannuation schemes of this type, surely that is not in the best interests of the community as a whole. We want to see the spouse able to depend on the deceased spouses' investment rather than to have to turn to the welfare of the State.

I also touch briefly on the subject of sales tax. This touches the indirect tax debate, a matter on which the Opposition has been criticised for raising and discussing. We have had the gall to raise the question of the correct balance between direct and indirect tax within our community. I am not surprised that members of the Labor Party are not participating in this part of the tax debate tonight. When one looks at their record on indirect tax-consumption taxes, that is-one finds some rather surprising facts. The first is that in this financial year sales tax revenue is estimated to be 9.1 per cent of total revenue. Sales tax has got up to nearly 10 per cent of total revenue-$7.1 billion, which is almost equivalent to the total corporate tax take. If we look more closely at the matter, we find that sales tax has increased at a faster rate than has any other of the Labor Government's taxes. As I have said, sales tax is simply another consumption tax. It is not a sales tax that is in all ways equitable, it can be argued to be inequitable. It is imposed on foods like ice cream, orange juice and snack foods, but not on some luxury items or items such as pornographic magazines, to name a few.

In addition to the sales tax examples I have just quoted, we must bear in mind the hefty excise duty and customs duties that are being paid as a result of this Government's policies. Excise duty, which is now indexed and is taxation by stealth, is imposed on petroleum, cigarettes and alcohol. In this financial year the duty is estimated to amount to $9.7 billion-over 10 per cent of the tax take. Customs duties amount to a further $3.2 billion, nearly 5 per cent of the total tax take. As a percentage of total tax take, sales tax, excise duty and customs duty now represent a staggering 28.1 per cent-over $20 billion. Let not this Government criticise the Opposition for trying to find a correct balance between direct and indirect tax when we look at the massive escalation of indirect tax that has occurred under Labor policies.

In summary, we are examining these tax Bills in a depressing atmosphere. I submit that they amount to an indictment of this Government's taxation performance. The Bills attempt to remedy past errors-and it is a pity that the errors existed and that the Government did not get its tax legislation right in the first instance. The Government legislates announcements that were made a long time ago, in some instances almost two years ago. Anyone looking at the matter objectively would regard it as unsatisfactory tax law. The legislation makes proposals for reform in the international sphere that are simply not competitive and therefore will not produce the benefits that are claimed. It reinforces the inequity that has been evident in the Government's policies against families. Those inequities have been shown up in its direct taxes and specifically in relation to this debate in the massive growth of its indirect tax-sales tax, excise duties and customs duty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill and to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Short. In this debate I shall direct my remarks to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill and its effects on the people and industries of the rural and mining areas. How this Bill affects the bulk of the population has been very ably put by numerous of my own colleagues. This amendment Bill is but another in the string of Government moves to deal with the taxation system on an ad hoc basis, and generally with a knee-jerk reaction. It is well documented that this Government is now the highest taxing government ever in the postwar history of Australia. An estimated 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only has this Government a record number of taxpayers in the highest tax bracket, but it has pushed up company tax to a record 49 per cent. In 1983 it introduced the fringe benefits tax (FBT)-a tax that falls heaviest on the inland industries. This tax has collected far in excess of what the Government said it intended to collect in the first place. In this Budget an estimated $750m in fringe benefits tax is to be collected, an increase of 40.1 per cent. I say that it falls heaviest in the country because industry has no option but to build homes or to supply cheap accommodation. If these measures are not taken in the country we will not get men to man the farms and the mines, and country businesses will not be able to carry on. Fuel taxes have gone from 6c a litre to 20c a litre in the life of this Government. With country areas being very dependent on road travel for the transport of people, input of goods and outward transport of production, this tax is hitting those areas twice as hard. With this record collection of fuel tax, the Government is doing the country twice the injustice. It is returning a record lower amount to local government in the percentage of fuel tax collected. With no increase in the last four years, there has been in effect a 40 per cent reduction in finance going to local roads in real terms.

I turn to the subject of capital gains tax-the tax that the Government told us was not to be introduced. When the Government did introduce it, again we were told that the collections would not amount to a great deal. One has only to look at the projected collection figures for 1990 and beyond to see for oneself what the Government will eventually collect. With capital gains tax along came its anomalies. Ask any share trader during the 1987 share market boom what all this means, when share traders are trying to offset losses on shares against profits on other shares. It is a one way track to the Australian Taxation Office. Incidentally, I received a letter today from the Taxpayers' Association of Western Australia and I should like to quote that letter briefly:

We understand that the Taxation Office are shortly to issue assessments to taxpayers whereby profits on disposal of property with 12 months are assessed under section 26aaa and losses on disposal of property within 12 months are treated as a capital loss.
A simple example would be a taxpayer with two transactions, one resulting in a profit of $30,000 and one in a loss of $30,000.

In other words, the net result is nil-he would not make any money nor would he lose any. He would simply receive a tax bill on $30,000, at the highest rate, of $12,000 or $13,000 and, the same amount plus 11 per cent for provisional tax. He would receive a total bill of over $30,000 even though he has not made a profit. That speaks for itself.

In relation to sales tax, we have the biggest lie that any government could ever perpetrate. The Government is running around making big noises about consumption tax. Sales tax collections totalled $6.38 billion in 1986-87, which is 10.8 per cent greater than in 1985-86. The projection for 1987-88 is that it will rise by another 12 per cent. Sales tax collections as a proportion of total revenue in 1987-88 are 9.1 per cent. The consumption tax of this Government is greater than anything mooted by anyone else. The only difference is that it is not a flat rate. The Government should get its priorities right in relation to sales tax, but it chooses to apply sales tax on such basic commodities as orange juice, flavoured milk, snack foods, bathroom fittings and everyday household items including bread; at the same time it excludes pornographic material.

Sales tax is heavier, believe it or not, on those who live in the country. This is because it is mandatory for country retailers to charge sales tax on the `into stock' cost rather than the wholesaler cost. One of the greatest `honours' of living in a country area which is 80 per cent urbanised is that one must pay sales tax and other costs on freight, and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do it in the Northern Territory every day on everything.

—That is correct. So much for Senator Walsh's cry that the Liberal Party would place a consumption tax on the pies eaten in the outer at the football. I doubt whether Senator Walsh has eaten many pies in the outer at the football, whether in Kellerberrin, Melbourne or anywhere else. Children in the country, where 10.5 per cent of the population provide 84 per cent of Australia's export income, pay a consumption tax not only on the ice-cream they eat at the local football but on the freight that takes the ice-cream to the various towns. So much for the sham of no consumption tax, which has been mooted by honourable senators opposite!

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has also introduced sales tax on agricultural input costs. If senators do not believe me they have only to look at the sales tax of 20 per cent on farm lubricants. We considered it to be a production cost and it was an item exempt prior to the 1983-84 Budget. This tax on farm lubricants was applied just in case farmers used them-mainly grease and high grade high detergent diesel motor oil-in their cars. That is a very unlikely event unless they possess a diesel Mercedes.

I now turn to one of my favourite subjects-superannuation. We have seen under this Government the introduction of a tax on superannuation, and we will probably see more later on this year with the help of the Democrats-and I will return to them later. It could be said that the Australian population through the golden years of the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and early 1980s, when we had full employment--

TALK.START.PARA: —And no Democrats.

—That is correct, Senator Short-and no Democrats. During those golden years there was a choice of many jobs when one completed one's education and, in fact, the population expected these golden years to keep rolling on. The House of Representatives Hansard of 17 February shows that the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) pointed out during debate on this Bill that Australia should have made a big drive in superannuation in 1948. I do not expect that the ideology of Mr Edwards on superannuation would be the same as mine, but I can only say how right he was. During the good years people with foresight generally built up their superannuation and property to tide them over in their old age. Trying to make up for lost time, this Government now comes along and imposes tax on those funds-I am sure with more to come-and capital gains tax on property that they have put aside. This was all done on the pretext of preventing double dipping. I maintain that double dipping came about because of the lowering of retirement age to 55. This gave people 10 years, if they so wished, to arrange that sort of double dipping. However, in retirement, with the present costs and taxes, one will probably run out of funds in 10 years, anyhow.

SPEECH.PARA: I now return to the Democrats before I forget. Last week Senator Powell decried the fact that some people retire with $200,000 in superannuation while others to so with only $100,000 and said that she could not see why there was a difference. Is there no reward for excellence and supreme effort in this world any more? What hypocrites the Democrats are in this place. There probably is not one Democrat in this place who has risked a dollar in his or her life, yet the Democrats have the gall to berate people who have worked hard in a profession or a business or as an ordinary worker and saved their money. Those who took the risk or deprived themselves in younger years have paid heaps of taxes and have provided for the less fortunate and the less willing. They have provided for their retirement, yet hypocrites gripe.

In Italy, which now has its forty-eighth government-give or take a couple-since the war, people who have retired as early as 45 for life on a pension that they have provided for themselves are not taxed to high heaven by the Government. Australia would do well to look at the system in that country. Before I finish with the Democrats, I remember Senator Haines last year carping that the Government was reintroducing negative gearing-taking away from the poor to sop the rich. If Senator Haines looked at the recent building figures, she would see how stupid her argument was. Since the reintroduction of negative gearing the number of buildings erected and sold around Australia has jumped. Of course negative gearing was another measure that the Government had to back down on, and I commend it for doing that. I could go on all evening but I will not do that. I support the amendment moved by Senator Short, which reads:
but the Senate notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and
(e) sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes;

(f) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86.77 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living.
I fully support that amendment, as do all my colleagues on this side who have contributed to this debate.

I shall conclude with a few sobering thoughts. As I have said before, in Australia an estimated 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue. Tax will increase by $5.5 billion on last year's collection. Taxation revenue for 1987-88 is estimated at $71 billion. Presently, our foreign debt is $83 billion. In 1985 it was $50.334 billion; in 1986 it was $73.879 billion; and in 1987 it was $82.178 billion. So, we have a $5 billion increase even on last year. Last year the Government raised company tax from 46c to 49c in the dollar. This was up 9.9 per cent in 1986-87 from the previous year. Comparing this corporate tax with that of our trade competitors, ours is 49c as against 18c in Hong Kong, 39c in Singapore-and there is a host of others, including New Zealand, that are far below us. I can see that we are fast running down the taxation hill in Australia and it is time that the Government sorted out its taxation measures in a proper and equitable way, rather than this ad hoc system that it has, with knee-jerk reactions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a wide-ranging debate to which mostly Opposition senators have contributed. It is not that Government senators are not interested in the matters that have been raised but, I guess, had we matched the Opposition in speakers, the program would have been put behind by another week. The various Opposition senators who have contributed to this debate have ranged far and wide on taxation matters. They have used it as an opportunity on which to get rid of those guilty feelings in their system that they have had for many years about their failure in the Fraser years to address any decent tax reform at all. We have this fairly long-winded and pious amendment added on which I, as a Government representative, certainly cannot accept.

SPEECH.PARA: The first part of the amendment refers to our being the highest taxing government in the post war history of Australia. It does not define what it means by the `highest'. Does it mean as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP)? What does it mean? Is it talking just in global terms? If so, that first part of the amendment is dishonest; and if it is not dishonest, it is irrelevant. The second part of the amendment refers to 24.5 per cent of GDP being collected in taxation. One could put a whole range of analysis into that but, at the very least, one could say that the Government is providing far more wide-ranging services to the community than a Liberal government ever would. There is no question that 24.5 per cent of GDP is not the highest figure in postwar history; it has been considerably higher than that over time.

In later parts of the amendment reference is made to new incentive-sapping taxes, like fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. It is the hoary old chestnut thrown out again by the Liberal Party; those opposite do not like fringe benefits taxes or capital gains taxes and they maintain that whenever they come back into power they will remove those taxes. What a great life it will be again-back into the free lunch and the free school fees, back into all the rorts and ramps in the tax system, which those opposite always failed to address and did nothing about. All the bludgers in the community will come back out and cheer the election of a Liberal government, so that they can get all the old entitlements put back.

I think it is time for the Opposition to show a bit of maturity. I can tell those opposite right now that if they ever won government again it is pounds to peanuts that they would never alter the fringe benefits tax or the capital gains tax. They would sit down on the first day of government and just as Greiner has said, `Time for a reassessment, the monorail stays, there will be just a small re-routing', those opposite would say, `Here we have the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, they exist and we cannot afford to do away with them'. Of course, they could not do away with them because they have been a monumentally successful venture by this Government, in taking the rorts and ramps out of the tax system. They have also been responsible for transferring other income and other tax into income tax, because there is no point any more in getting into a lot of these lurks, and thus they have increased income tax. So, again, this amendment has very little value.

Over the years we have seen a lot of changes by the Labor Party to the tax Act. It was in desperate need of repair. The only time that I have ever seen in this chamber the Liberals get excited about taxation was during 1982 when the McCabe-Lafranchi report came out, followed by the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Suddenly the panic was on in this chamber; suddenly something had to be done about tax avoidance schemes-not because those opposite particularly condemned tax avoidance schemes but because it meant that they would be kicked out of office if they did not try to do something about the matter. We saw a majority of Liberal senators come over and vote with the Labor Party to establish retrospectivity in relation to these matters. They included Senator Watson and other honourable senators opposite. They came over and supported retrospectivity. They have never supported it since, because their reason for supporting it then was all based on electoral survival. If it was such an inviolable principle then, one wonders why they have never supported it since, thus depriving this Government, or any government, of much needed tax revenue. The moment retrospectivity is introduced all tax avoidance schemes go down the tubes.

The Government rejects the Opposition's second reading amendment. Whether or not it is passed will not be of great moment in the world; plenty of second reading amendments go through and unfortunately, or fortunately, it is the last we ever hear of them. These sorts of tax measures are vital for us to clean up the tax Act and get a clear exposition of what the taxation necessities in this country are. I wish the Bills a relatively speedy passage.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Short's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address some of the clauses in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 with reference to the roll-over annuity tax provisions. I refer basically to clauses 11, 17, 18 and 19, which give effect to the proposal which was announced, as many proposals are announced, by Press release. This one was announced in January this year. It provides for new eligibility conditions for roll-over annuities. I raise this point in committee because I think it is important to draw the attention of the Government, perhaps in general terms, to some of the problems of legislation by Press release, although, as has already been noted in the debate on this legislation, the Bill is perhaps remarkable in that it has been introduced relatively soon after the Press release announcing these provisions as opposed to some other cases where more time has elapsed.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, I raise the matter because it has caused considerable problems for individuals. Individuals have not been able to prove that their intentions were such that, had the Press release not been issued on the day it had, they would not have been disadvantaged but, because the statement was made and the Government's intention was made clear, they now are suffering a disadvantage. I was contacted by a constituent of mine in this very situation. I think the difficulty here occurs when the situation is out of the control of the individual. In this case the constituent's lump sum was due on 6 January 1987 and the only reason that the investment was not made before the announcement, which precluded the arrangements into which he was going to enter, was delays in the operations of the State Superannuation Board of Victoria. The constituent concerned contacted, I think, the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation, who replied:
Whilst this office is unable to offer firm advice until amending legislation has been enacted-
that, of course, is the legislation we are now addressing-

it would appear that you will be affected by the proposed changes as, despite your intentions on or before 12 January 1987, you had not entered into a legally enforceable contract to purchase the annuity as at that date.
The point the constituent makes to me is that in his case, at least to a certain extent, the legislation which we are now debating is in effect retrospective. As he says in his letter to me:

Those retirees, like myself, who had completed all the documents necessary for depositing their lump sum before 13th January 1987 should be allowed to invest their lump sum under the regulations which existed before 13th January, especially when payment was delayed by a State Superannuation Board.

I simply raise this case, which I am sure is not isolated, for the attention of the Minister and the Government to indicate the continuing problem that once there are cut-off dates and levels in any legislation or regulation this causes problems. But I think in enacting legislation such as this we should be aware that such situations arise. In this case it has been indicated that paperwork was completed, so there was obviously documented, dated and, no doubt, witnessed evidence that this transaction was all but completed before that time. We should bear this in mind and make a genuine attempt to redress any similar problems in future cases.
Bills agreed to.
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 reported without amendment and Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987 reported without requests; reports adopted.
