DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (MAINTENANCE INCOME TEST) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 April, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding to the details of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill 1988, it is relevant to make a point that perhaps should be made more often in the media. Certainly parliamentarians should make this point in the community. One so often hears of the public perception of Parliament as a place where rowdy battles ensue, although perhaps more so in the lower House than here, and where partisan politics override goodwill and commonsense. It is a matter of regret that we so rarely read of the occasions such as tonight when we agree, not only on what the problem is, but also on the manner in which it should be resolved. We have supported the earlier elements of this package of Bills, although `package' is perhaps somewhat too bipartisan a word to use to describe the Bills that have come before us. I say that because arguably it would be much better if the Bills dealing with this matter, that is, improvements in the collection of child maintenance, had come in together. We could then perhaps have debated them cognately. That is not suggested in terms of speeding debating time or reducing the number of speeches as a consequence of a cognate debate, but in terms of having a sensible debate in which one can address the full range of issues in one speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The centrepiece of the Government's child support scheme was the Child Support Act, followed by the Family Law Amendment Act. There is no point in repeating elements of speeches that were made on those two Bills. Suffice it to say that it is monumental hypocrisy, in my view, on the part of this Government to reject the consistent attempts by Senator Durack to have some elements of the Family Law Act amended that would go a long way towards doing what the Government has finally come around to doing. Senator Durack's attempts were consistently rejected. It seems a pity that the people whom those amendments could have benefited had to wait so long to get them when at least that part of it could have been done before. I recall arguments put forward by Senator Crowley that it was not appropriate to do this in a piecemeal fashion; it had to be done in one big load. This legislation is not being taken as one group, either. It has to be taken separately. I do not believe that to be a satisfactory reason for rejecting the very sensible and proper amendments that were suggested by Senator Durack some time ago-almost two years ago, I think.

The object of the series of Bills is to ensure that those who have the financial capacity do not discard their responsibility to their children. This will increase the number of families receiving maintenance and the amount of maintenance they receive. I wish to repeat some remarks I made about sole parents in a debate in one of the earlier Bills. We frequently hear in the community that it is sole parents who are a drain on welfare, and a variety of other negative remarks. We seem to forget that, unless immaculate conception has become a daily occurrence as opposed to a miracle, there are no sole parents. There may be deserted parents and sole surviving parents but there are no children who have only ever had one parent. Therefore, when we refer to sole parents we mean people who are living without partners, trying desperately to bring up their kids, with inadequate support because the community has turned away from the responsibility of making them responsible. It is in recognition of this appalling situation that the Government has brought forward this package of Bills and that we are supporting it.

This Bill details the interrelationship between the still developing child support scheme and social security entitlements. It introduces a separate income test on maintenance received. The maintenance which attracts this test will take a variety of forms, some of which have previously escaped attention, or assessment. The most obvious form of maintenance that can be paid to a custodial parent is regular cash maintenance. Two other sorts of maintenance will now be caught in the maintenance test; in kind maintenance, which may take the form of school fees, health insurance premiums, power bills and some forms of housing assistance and last, but certainly not least, capitalised maintenance, big lump sums of cash and share settlements and, obviously, other forms.

It is a good thing that the variety of maintenance that has been paid for many years will now be caught by this test. There are people who have had the capacity to be paid what, in reality, has been maintenance in ways that have escaped social security income testing, so putting themselves in a substantially better position vis-a-vis the collection of social security than someone who has not had those kinds of resources and been able so to arrange their affairs. In that respect, as in many others, it is a gigantic improvement.

The Bill contains hardship provisions which ensure that benefits or allowances will not be reduced by more than 25 per cent. In discussions with, admittedly, the very helpful staff of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), I asked whether someone-there might be only one or two people in this position-who had settled upon her a very small sum of cash maintenance but a multi-million dollar house, something like Paradis Sur Mer, someone with little income but huge assets, would still lose only 25 per cent of her pension. The answer was yes. I confess to not having pursued the matter and to some surprise if that really is the case. But no system is perfect and this system is a gigantic improvement on what has been operating in the past.

Provision is also made in the Bill for sole parents to be required to take reasonable action to obtain available maintenance before they can qualify for a benefit. A balance will need to be struck in this matter between the interests of the community, which are obviously not served by allowing individuals to say to the taxpayer that they do not want to pursue avenues of maintenance that are open to them, for a whole variety of personal and undisclosed reasons-that would not be acceptable-and the interests of individuals in sensitive situations. There are sensitive situations in which women, in particular, are not keen to pursue a father for maintenance. Fears of domestic violence are not low on the list in that category.

The Government is on the right track with this Bill, but it would not assume that our support for these measures indicates general support for what it has done to Australian families across the board. After all, one good move does not clear the decks for everything else. It is in acknowledgment of that view that I propose to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. I will not debate the amendment because I think it has been phrased so as to make abundantly clear what we think this Government has done to Australian families. While, admittedly, it has fixed this aspect of the problem-an important and serious aspect-it has let down other areas very badly by paying inadequate attention to them. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate deplores the fact that the economic and social policies pursued by the Hawke Government since March 1983 have directly contributed to the continuing high level of marriage break-ups by:
(a) increasing the number of Australian families living below the poverty line and bearing the brunt of unemployment, including an additional 165,000 children;
(b) pursuing policies which have resulted in single income families on average weekly earnings with 2 children facing a decline of $42 a week in their standard of living in real terms;

(c) abolishing negative gearing between July 1985 and September 1987 which resulted in a decline in rental accommodation, and a steep rise in rental costs which has contributed to 160,000 Australians waiting for public housing, while thousands of families and individuals live in refuges, emergency accommodation or on the streets;
(d) failing to give recognition to the increased burdens of families with dependants other than the approximately 23% eligible for assistance under the Family Assistance Scheme; and
(e) contributing to a marked decline in the standard of living of veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel''.

That list is a very sad story that the Government must address. I will be interested to hear Government senators address each of those points. We cannot really have a debate on the proposals that have been put forward. As I hope I have made abundantly clear, we support them. There is really no point in everybody standing up to say that they support them. By moving this second reading amendment I have indicated that, while we support these measures, there are these other issues that we think the Government should address. If it is really concerned about Australian families it should consider that not just sole parent families need assistance. All families would be affected by these actions. Sole-parent families would also benefit if the Government cleaned up its act in this regard. I look forward in the debate to hearing what Government senators have to say with respect to the five points which we say are indicative of the appalling economic and social record of the Hawke Government in relation to families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: 9.43)-As the previous speaker, Senator Vanstone, has indicated, tonight we are looking at the third part of a package of legislation which is designed to bring to children in particular much more support-we are dealing here with financial support-from their non-custodial parent in instances where the partnership, be it marriage or otherwise, has broken down for one reason or another. It is a set of measures which has gained multi-partisan support in the Parliament. It has been a matter of great regret and probably some shame to most of us in the community that a very high proportion of non-custodial parents have not been contributing adequately-and in many cases not at all-to the ongoing welfare of their children once partnerships have broken down. That is the first point. The second point-perhaps, unfortunately, I might take the cynical view-is that a major motivating force for getting this legislation before us from this or any other government is that that process has led to a very great drain on the public purse. The result has been that very many children and their supporting parent-largely the mother-have become dependent upon social security payments of one kind or another, particularly supporting parent benefit payments and other children's payments.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important in this debate to make it clear that the majority of the people we are talking about are children and their female parents, although that is not absolutely the case. It appears from recent figures that increasing numbers of male parents are being granted custody of their children by the Family Court of Australia. When we debated the Child Support Bill in this place a few weeks ago I made the comment that as increasing numbers of male parents become responsible for their children we may see an exponential rise in changes in attitudes towards sole supporting parents and, in general, changes in attitudes towards parenting, so that we might reach the stage where parenting is seen as a joint responsibility, not simply as the responsibility of female parents.

I say that not because I am a female parent but because I believe it is greatly to the detriment, not just of mothers, who have the burden of almost total responsibility, even in intact families, for their children, but also of children, who do not always-perhaps all too often this is the case-have sufficient emotional as well as financial support from their male parents. In our traditional society we have largely said to men, `This really isn't your business. Go out there and earn the money so that we can have a comfortable existence'. I deplore that as much as I deplore the problem we are addressing here of males turning a blind eye to their responsibilities.

I hope that some of the trends that we are seeing will escalate and that the children will benefit from joint parenting. Joint parenting can only advantage men in our society, because along with burdening them almost totally through most of modern times with the breadwinning role we have excluded them from caring and nurturing in our society. I think that the trends now are much better as far as men are concerned. They are able to experience all aspects of parenting, not just the financial responsibilities. Tonight we are talking mainly about those parents who have been, in a sense, dodging their financial responsibilities.

I would also like to make it clear that while the Australian Democrats have supported this package of legislation-including the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Bill-we do not see it as a perfect solution by any means. In fact, I felt as though I had been goaded almost into opposition by the sorts of statements that are constantly made in reference to this legislation by members of the Government and, in particular, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as part of the claim that no child need live in poverty by 1990-or, according to the policy speech before the last election, no child will live in poverty by 1990. To say that this piece of legislation is perfect in that context is quite wrong. This Bill fails to do anything for quite a significant group of sole-parent children. When we are talking about collecting maintenance and establishing systems for collecting maintenance, we are not bringing into the ambit those children, for instance, who do not have a second parent as a result of one parent having been widowed, whose non-custodial parent cannot be found for one reason or another, or whose non-custodial parent simply does not have any money to pay maintenance.

I know that the Government implemented other measures, such as the family allowance supplement, in the last Budget as part of its family package. Let us look at that family allowance supplement. It is designed to go to all children who live in families which meet the income tests, which are, I believe, quite generous and useful in helping provide more income for those families, but it does not go any more to those children I have spoken of. Sole-parent families are relying on this package for increased support. I am saying that there are still a lot of children living in poverty, living in sole-parent families, who are not picked up by this. When we add that to the fact that the family allowance supplement has been taken up by what the Government believes to be only about 50 per cent of the people who are eligible-that may have gone up in the last week or two, but that is the last figure I have seen-we have to believe that there are more and more out there who are not getting the full benefits of the family package.

I think it is important to express those reservations and to point out, as I pointed out when we were speaking on the Child Support Bill, the first of this group of measures after we had dealt with the Family Court of Australia amendments, that for maintenance legislation to help all children in sole-parent families it would have to contain a maintenance guarantee. Such a guaranteed maintenance should be payable to all custodial parents who do not receive maintenance above the level that would be set for such a guarantee. As I have said, there are significant groups of children, along with their parents, in that category. In fact, it could be based on eligibility for the family allowance, since that is now an income tested benefit. The guarantee would recognise the fact that when many family breakdowns occur there is often a period before maintenance collection, even under this new system we are setting up, can be set in train. A maintenance guarantee which came into place immediately upon breakdown could fill in that gap and be paid while maintenance liabilities were being determined, and then be recouped later where the payments come in above that guaranteed level.

It is important that we recognise that this is a flaw in this whole package, that there are people who are missing out, and that something of this nature is still very much required. This is one of the recommendations of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) and various of its affiliated bodies. The ACOSS submission to the Government in relation to the May Budget statement this year makes that point. ACOSS has costed its proposal, which it feels could be phased in at reasonably low levels. In fact, it suggested the significantly low level of just $5 a week per child to be introduced in December of this year, with subsequent increases to $15 a week and so on, these rates to be indexed. Its costing for the first year is $35m. This is, we should be reminded, a system being introduced by the Government which will save it considerable money. In the face of those savings it really is not too much to ask that they be spent on child support of one kind or another. When we know there is a group of children whose needs are not being met by this package of legislation and when we are told in the financial impact statement of the legislation that the package so far would give a net gain of $120m in 1988-89 and $192m in 1989-90, with further savings beyond that, I really do not think it is too much to ask for a maintenance guarantee which would cost some $35m in the first year.

The Australian Democrats have said all along about this package of maintenance legislation-and it has been said also by many community groups concerned with children and particularly with the children of sole parents, such as the Council of the Single Mother and her Child-that this should not be a measure which will boost the Government's coffers. It should be a measure to redistribute to all children in need the money which is currently in the kitty, if you like, for child welfare payments and which is boosted as a result of the collection of maintenance from people who should be paying maintenance.

ACOSS has also been critical, as have a number of other groups and individuals concerned with this legislation, that the free area is too low at $15, and $5 for subsequent children, and that that should be raised. ACOSS makes a more costly recommendation, which would involve $76m, but I believe it is part of what I have suggested ought to be a redistributive piece of legislation rather than legislation to swell the Government's coffers and help us to balance our Budget, if not have a surplus. There is also a proposal from ACOSS which addresses the issue of those children for whom maintenance collection is no advantage, and that is that the mother's guardian's allowance be increased from $12 a week to $20 a week. These are the sorts of proposals which the Democrats believe should be given very serious consideration in the context of this legislation.

As Senator Vanstone has said, it is significant that we do have a considerable degree of multipartisan support for this legislation, but again I do not think we should fool ourselves that we are necessarily going a very long way down the track in relation to this issue which concerns so many of us-the issue of children living in poverty. It is useful that we have and that the Government has spearheaded a recognition of the problem of children in poverty. It has been difficult to raise in the community the consciousness of poverty-which of course has been increasing, to our shame, in recent years, very much because of employment difficulties for people. Even in the face of an increasing number of jobs, the distribution of work and the problems of people being in the right place at the right time with the right qualifications and so on are still causing enormous difficulties. Addressing child poverty in the very direct way that the Government is doing it is a major contribution to having us face up to our responsibilities as a community, and a community in which increasing numbers of people are living in poverty.

Of course, anything we can do to help in that circumstance we all want to do, but I draw to the attention of honourable senators and even of people in the other place-members of the Government in particular but also those who may think that they could be an alternative government-a particularly significant contribution in the debate on poverty in Australia which I had the honour to hear being given by Don Edgar, the Director of the Australian Institute of Family Studies, in Melbourne a week or so ago at a national conference on child poverty sponsored jointly by the Institute of Family Studies and ACOSS. I thought Don Edgar's opening address to that conference was, as I said, a significant contribution to the debate on poverty in Australia. There is not a great deal of time to go through his address point by point, nor is there much profit in doing so, but I would like to make a couple of the points which he made because, while we are passing specific legislation to address a specific problem, we should never lose sight of the overall problem and the overall issues. Don Edgar said-I think this is something that we all need to take note of:
Poverty is not merely a lack of financial resources.

In many cases, for all the additional $5 here, $10 there, indexation here and maintenance collection there, we can be comforted into believing that we are making significant inroads if we believe that poverty is merely a lack of financial resources. Don Edgar went on to say:

It is a denial of power and hence responsibility. Inequality leaves power and responsibility in the hands of the better off, the `over-rewarded' who, we know, feel less of a sense of unfairness about their ratio of reward exceeding their input than do those whose efforts are not adequately rewarded.

I think that is something that we should all bear in mind. If we are going to eliminate poverty in this country, we should be doing a great deal more than putting some dollars in some people's pockets. At another point he addressed this very issue, relating it to the question of employment and to research work that has been done in that area. There has been ample work in this area, of course. He said in his speech:
The most common ways of entering and leaving poverty were changes in employment-related earnings and changes in family composition.
Of course, we are specifically addressing family composition changes in this legislation. He went on to say:

So the poverty debate in Australia must not talk as if `the poor' comprises one group that can be `targetted'. It must address `the poverty' into which varied types of people are pushed by structural changes in employment and family life. Thus, targetting payments to the poor may alleviate some of the temporary disadvantages they suffer, but only programs which address the broader causes which push people into poverty and keep them down and out will solve the poverty problem.

Perhaps the major point that Don Edgar made in his speech was that we need a new social compact if we are to address issues of poverty in any substantive way. I certainly recommend this speech to people who are concerned, as I think all those who have participated in this debate and previous debates on this legislation have demonstrated they are. I think it is useful to point in that direction. It is important to pick up a couple of points again just to make sure that we do not think that what we are doing here will have an enormous effect in the form of those structural changes and social resources to which all people need equal access if they are to avoid falling into poverty. For instance, on the question of housing it is increasingly being recognised that people from time to time in the pattern of their lives find it difficult to make ends meet and are falling below the poverty line which we have established as a measure. It will not necessarily help if we put a few more dollars in the pockets of these families if there is not adequate housing for them at reasonable rates and if the only housing available is, for instance, private rental housing. Recent research clearly shows that this is a major factor involved in people-in particular, families with children and, most particularly, sole parents with children in their care-falling below the poverty line.

Senator Vanstone moved an amendment to the second reading motion. Before addressing those points specifically, I would like to point out one area that we have to think about-I am sure we all do-when addressing problems of children in particular and of families who do not have adequate incomes, who are powerless and whose lives are a misery as a result. I am looking at some recent figures on child abuse which were part of an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday and which draw a link between poverty and child abuse. We are doing much more here than simply trying to see that people have enough money for food; we are trying to alleviate as far as possible the stresses and the consequences of poverty.

Senator Vanstone's second reading amendment, as with many second reading amendments, makes statements which can be supported and statements which are not necessarily supported. I think we all deplore the fact that the number of families living below the poverty line is increasing. One of the reasons why we are all supporting this legislation is that we believe that it goes at least some of the way to addressing that problem. However, the Democrats cannot support paragraph (c) of the amendment, which relates to the abolition of negative gearing and a decline in rental accommodation.

Earlier tonight in another debate Opposition speakers proclaimed loudly that the reintroduction of negative gearing has made a significant difference to the housing industry. But I think we need to be more than simplistic about it and recognise that what is happening in the building industry is largely, if not exclusively, an increase in the building of accommodation which is far beyond the reach of the sort of people that we are talking about here. When the Government reintroduced negative gearing in the last Budget, on which the Opposition congratulated it here tonight, the Australian Democrats said that it was not an answer to the housing problem. It is certainly not an answer to the housing problem for the very people we are talking about in this legislation. Those people need low cost housing. In large measure that will be housing under a variety of kinds of cooperative and mixed administration, but particularly public housing. The Government's record here is not good in that State governments have been squeezed. Since public housing is, in large measure, the direct responsibility of State governments, this has been a major problem at State level and one which, in the new federalism that we have seen from this Government, has been passed off like the inevitable buck that is passed down the line. Those who have suffered are the people in the low income groups, particularly the people we are addressing in this legislation-sole parent families.

The question of public housing is not directly addressed by the negative gearing issue. That is a point which the Democrats have made quite often. In legislation which we all support, for all the reasons that we have already heard and will hear in this debate, it is not particularly helpful to make the sorts of points made in the Opposition's amendment, and the Democrats do not see any particular advantage at this point in supporting that amendment. We will have some questions to raise in the committee stage about specific issues in the legislation, particularly with regard to some concerns we have about the administrative arrangements. But at this point of the second reading debate I think it is important to say that the Democrats agree that this legislation goes in the right direction.

We are very unhappy about the fact that it is seen not so much as a redistributive measure but as something which has a bottom line with a plus sign in front of it when it comes to the financial impact of the legislation. We would have much preferred to have seen a commitment by the Government to a redistributive process through a maintenance guarantee. We hope that some of the pressures which are now operating on the Government and some of the messages which the Government is getting and which say that it is not going far enough in meeting and understanding the needs of the electorate and that it is much more concerned with doing things for some of its big business mates are getting through. We hope that Mr Howe, the Minister who introduced this Bill in the House of Representatives and who, just last weekend in Melbourne at the conference of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party conference, had quite a bit to say on this subject, will be able to give us some good news in the near future about a maintenance guarantee and an increase in the levels of the income test free areas in this legislation, in recognition of the fact that it is important that we eliminate child poverty and that we look at this kind of legislation in a redistributive fashion and not just as an exercise in balancing the books.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill 1988. As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said in his second reading speech, it is the second part of the Child Support Act 1988. That Act set up an agency for the collection of family maintenance. As such, the Bill before the Senate is being supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deals with the support of the many hundreds of thousands of children who have been affected by marriage breakup. The latest figures show that in 1986 there was one divorce for every 2.9 marriages-horrific figures. These figures mean that in 1986 alone there were 45,200 children affected by divorce-an incredibly large figure and one that substantiates the Minister's claim that 400,000 children have been affected by this trauma. As I have said, the Opposition supports the intention of the Bill. Indeed, as I pointed out in this chamber when we were debating the Child Support Bill in February of this year, it was the Opposition-indeed, Senator Durack-which, as far back as 1983, instigated the principle in these amendments, and the Government and the Democrats voted against it. In 1975, when Senator Durack brought in a private member's Bill, he pointed out all the problems that this Bill is now facing, and once again the Government and the Democrats voted against it. It surprised me to hear Senator Powell being so concerned tonight about the poverty of the supporting parents. This Bill, as she said tonight, does in some ways alleviate this poverty. This could have been done five years ago if the Democrats had voted with us. Senator Powell talked tonight as though suddenly, out of the blue, the penny has dropped and she now recognises that supporting parents are indeed living in poverty with many of their children, but she put forward no reason for the fact that her Party defeated this precise legislation five years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not here then.

—That statement is ridiculous, because the Australian Democrats certainly were. If she was sincere in her statement that she was not here then and, therefore, that is an excuse for not voting for us at that time, she should have put in her speech tonight the reasons why the Democrats now see that they were wrong five years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is acknowledged by all parties that the supporting mother, struggling without maintenance to bring up her children, is in the poorest section of our community. She is, as I say, left struggling to bring up her children, and at times here problems all become too great for her. Yet, because of the stupidity of the Government and the Democrats, these mothers have had to struggle for an additional five years and bear the brunt of poverty. We could have passed this sort of legislation in 1983 if we had had the support of the whole Senate.

A few years after the defeat of our Bill, Mr Hawke was scrambling around for a good election gimmick and he gave the people that well known cynical promise that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990. Because of the rubbishing he got for making that statement he changed, or attempted to change, those words. Nevertheless, the words he used were that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990. He does not like to be reminded of those words because there are so many children living in poverty, not only those being supported by the custodial parents surviving without maintenance but also the very large number-an estimated 30,000 children-in the homeless youth brigade who, for a number of reasons, have been totally deserted by their natural parents. I hope that the plight of the homeless youth will be alleviated by the additional support given to the custodial parents of broken marriages because the survey proves that the majority of these young people come from broken families. The Minister's second reading speech states:

The Bill will bring into account a wide range of maintenance income received by social security and veteran pensioners and beneficiaries. The most straightforward of these is cash maintenance paid on a regular basis. At present this is taken into account as income for only some pensions and benefits.
The Bill goes further in assessing maintenance for income and it has two additional types of maintenance. The first is in-kind maintenance, and that may take various forms. The Minister says:

For example it may be food provided, household items supplied, payments of medical benefits insurance, the provision of housing or payment of rent, payments of household accounts or educational or child care expenses.

The next type is the type of capital maintenance and takes into consideration such things as the house and lump sum capital expenditures and capital payments, and these, of course, will be taken into account as maintenance for the first time. There are the two new areas of assessing maintenance which is not simply cash. However, the maintenance income test is less severe than other forms of income testing.

The aim of the Bill is to ensure the payment of maintenance by the new custodial parent to the degree that has been decided on by the court and so shift the responsibility of maintaining the children who presently rely on social security to their parents. Consequently the Bill emphasises-and I refer to the Minister's second reading speech-the requirement that sole parents in order to qualify for pensions must take reasonable action to obtain available maintenance. `Reasonable action' is not defined in the Bill. However, it is set out in the Department of Social Security manual of instructions and I shall refer to a few of them. The condition is met where the claimant has instituted court proceedings in the matter; a court has refused to make an order or awarded only a small amount; voluntary maintenance is being paid; the claimant does not know the whereabouts of the other parent of the child; legal advice has been obtained to the effect that the court would be unlikely to make an order; the other parent of the child is a pensioner of beneficiary; or the name of the father of the child is unknown. It is the Department's policy that there are circumstances in which it would not be reasonable for a claimant to take action-for example, where there is fear of violence from the other party and similar issues.

The Government has said that these amendments along with the Child Support Act and the amendments to the Family Law Act will save the Government $120m in 1988-89 and $192.8m in 1989-90 and substantially more in future years. Senator Powell has made great play that if this is the case, the money will go into government coffers. I sincerely hope not. If these figures are anywhere near accurate, it means that this money can be returned to the taxpayer. If these figures are anywhere near accurate, it only means that if this type of legislation had indeed been instigated when the Opposition wanted it instigated five years ago, the taxpayers of this country would have been saved over $1 billion. The Government has been irresponsible in delaying this legislation. I have very much pleasure in supporting the Opposition's amendment, which reads as follows:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate deplores the fact that the economic and social policies pursued by the Hawke Government since March 1983 have directly contributed to the continuing high level of marriage break-ups by:
(a) increasing the number of Australian families living below the poverty line and bearing the brunt of unemployment, including an additional 165,000 children;
(b) pursuing policies which have resulted in single income families on average weekly earnings with 2 children facing a decline of $42 a week in their standard of living in real terms;

(c) abolishing negative gearing between July 1985 and September 1987 which resulted in a decline in rental accommodation, and a steep rise in rental costs which has contributed to 160,000 Australians waiting for public housing, while thousands of families and individuals live in refuges, emergency accommodation or on the streets;
(d) failing to give recognition to the increased burdens of families with dependants other than the approximately 23% eligible for assistance under the Family Assistance Scheme; and
(e) contributing to a marked decline in the standard of living of veterans, war widows, ex-service personnel and serving personnel''.

I have noted that no Labor senators intend to speak on this Bill. Indeed, no Labor senator spoke on the previous Bill, and it surprises me that the Government can pass legislation without the support of its back bench.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
